149832310.review:
I desperately wanted to like this game. I pre-ordered it after I connected with the devs prior game, Everlasting Summer. Naturally, that game was the point of comparison to this one.

I'll start with the things I enjoyed about this game.
The visuals and music are both very well done, and are very effective at selling the atmosphere of the game. The few lyrical tracks were a highlight.
The games choices are very well designed, and you can intuitively and easily get onto the route of your choice.
Unfortunately that is where my positive things to say ends.

This game does not have four routes, it has two. The girls are paired off into their own routes, and they only diverge in the epilogue. What this means is that you'll pick one route (for this example, we'll say Ellie) and you end up spending half of the games runtime with a character you most likely do not care about (Kagome).

And the only reason that is a problem is because of the character writing. Characters are given one (usually archetypal) character trait, and past that have zero consistent writing or psychology. The story's plot is driven solely by artificial conflict caused by the characters seemingly deciding to act a certain way with no explanation, as every single conversation devolves into circular arguments where none of the characters even attempt explain themselves.

This problem also extends to the main character, which seems to be the main complaint looking at other reviews. And, yeah, he is insufferable, again solely to move the plot forward. Everlasting Summer had a main character that was sometimes insufferable as well, but that played into the core plot of the game, which was about the MC growing as a person. There is no such plot in this game.

What disappointed me the most was the absolutely insane tonal dissonance during my first playthrough, which was Ellie's route. I played the Demo of the game, liked her the best (love band storylines), and pre-ordered the game. I still quite like the first opening act of the game, where you essentially pick the route you take. It's light and kind of fluffy, the tone I'd expect from a romance visual novel. But as soon as i got into the meat of the games routes, and the circular argumentative dialogue begins, the fun band storyline I wanted is abruptly and messily intercut with [spoiler] the KGB is monitoring me, a man has been kidnapped [/spoiler] , only for when I lock into a single characters route to have all that sloppily dropped in an instant.

The epilogue for Ellie's route had its own issues as well, stemming from the same issues the rest of the game has, and that is it's need for pointless conflict to drive the plot forward. It brings up incredibly serious subject matter with absolutely zero tact or care, seemingly to try to shock you into getting invested.

And funnily enough, I got to the ending of the route, and I liked it. It fit the tone the start of the game had, which makes me believe they had the endings and act 1 written first, and then desperately scrambled to make all the routes fit together, making this incomprehensible slurry of plot points and nonexistent motivations.

tl;dr: Overly-long, poorly written routes and characters, and generally less charming or enjoyable than Everlasting Summer.

I don't know if I'll ever lock in to finish all the routes of this game, but between my sheer disappointment and how obnoxiously long these routes are, it won't be anytime soon.

146729405.review:
[h1]Честно говоря, после полного прохождения игры остались двоякие чувства[/h1]

[u]Начнем с плюсов:[/u]

Отличные арты, спрайты персонажей, анимации, музыка (все треки с вокалом отправились в плейлист),
тонны отсылок, приятное чтение (несмотря на объемы текста), Рут Эли и Кетрин.

[u]Теперь минусы:[/u]

Графомания, Рита почему-то решил, что лить воду как только можно, это отличное решение, ОЧЕНЬ много текста, хоть он и написан неплохо, просто устаешь.
Нелогичность некоторых событий, излишняя истеричность ГГ (но я смирился с ней)
Недосказанность, каждый рут нельзя считать полноценным без прохождения других рутов, вы просто не поймете проблемы героев.

Дальше спойлеры

[spoiler] Рут Кагомэ (я ее просто блять ненавижу, на этом все про этого персонажа) 
В названии игры фигурирует Деньги, Любовь, Рок-н-Ролл, когда рок важен только в руте Эли.
Непонятные действия второстепенных героев и их желание поднасрать ГГ, если ты выбрал не их.
Когда в одном Руте Ито (отец Химицу) является нейтральным для тебя персонажем, в другом он просто враг, в третьем он вообще не существует (не появляется в линии Эли/Кагомэ).
Другой случай, когда ЦРУ и японская разведка - это один рут, в другом же только КГБ и Корпорация. Их влияние в каждом отдельном руте просто без причины снижается. [/spoiler]
Здесь спойлеры кончаются.

[u]Подведу итог лично для себя[/u]

Я действительно с удовольствием провел 50 часов в этой игре, мне нравилось следить за событиями, мне нравилось развитие истории, ее в, мне нравилось развитие отношений (Эли и Кетрин), я не хотел заканчивать игру, хотел продолжение истории, более насыщенного наполнения.
Черт, да я плакал на плохой концовке Эли, там действительно была драма.
Несмотря на все минусы и все те проблемы, которые игра имеет, я все же порекомендую эту игру к покупке, но, НО вы должны понимать на что идете при покупке игры, не всем она понравится (далеко не всем).

Но свое место игра получила в моем сердце, это уж точно.

146080457.review:
Having played, enjoyed and been thoroughly mind-blown by Everlasting Summer, the previous visual novel from Soviet Games, I went into Love, Money, Rock'n'Roll (LMR) with high hopes and expectations. (In fact, high enough expectations to have pre-ordered and backed it during development.) Did it live up to them? Well... mostly, while even exceeding them in some areas.

The first thing to catch my eye was the absolutely stunning visual look of... everything, really. Every single detail seems very well thought out and executed, from the menus to the VHS fast-forward effects that show when skipping text. And the art is unlike anything I've ever come across in my - admittedly limited, compared to some - experience with visual novels. Right from the first scene, the art is absolutely breathtakingly beautiful, and as if that was not enough, nearly everything is animated: character movements, elements in the background, cherry petals blowing across the screen... It all comes together to immerse the player in the game's world, 1980s Tokyo. The effect this has on the overall playing experience cannot be overstated - they're called [b]visual[/b] novels for a reason, after all.

However, visuals are not the only section where LMR excels. The game features an absolutely massive soundtrack, with over five hours of music according to the devs. Despite the huge amount of music, I can't really name a single track that doesn't live up to the high level of quality set by the artwork. The soundtrack serves well to further paint a picture of the surrounding world, working especially well in routes and situations where music becomes part of the story. Not only that, but at times I found myself bopping my head or otherwise just jamming to the tunes, which I don't remember happening with other similar games. Personally, I'm usually not the biggest fan of having lyrics in my visual novel soundtracks, but LMR does its best to make me a believer. These songs are used sparingly and saved for hard-hitting moments, where they add a whole new layer of emotion.

World-class visuals? Check. Amazing soundtrack? Check. Writing? Well...

Don't get me wrong, the writing is not bad by any means. The characters are thought out well, there are no glaringly obvious inconsistencies in their actions or personalities. Most of them are actually rather fun to get to know closer, turning out to have actual depth to them. And not only the main heroines - I found myself looking forward to interactions with Nikolai's best friend, Kyosuke, who is admittedly kind of overlooked in the beginning but really proves himself toward the end of some of the paths. The story itself, a combination of the usual high school love affairs and a surprisingly complex spy thriller, is quite intriguing. It seems to be a trademark of Soviet Games to have stories full of dark mysteries and utterly unexpected twists of fate. Answers are often found where you'd least expect - a key mystery of one story path may be left unanswered, only for the truth to pop up in another playthrough. This is one of my favourite things about Soviet Games' products, as being able to piece the overall picture together bit by bit gives a massive boost to replay value.

Having said that, I found it hard to really properly get into LMR at first. After the initial excitement following its release, I found myself kind of lost with it. Yes, the visuals were stunning and the music was great, but I didn't really get the story at first. I had no idea if I was near the start, mid-point or end of the story, and it just... kept... going... on. When the end did eventually come, it felt quite abrupt, and most of my questions were left unanswered. To be fair, most of this was later explained in the other routes and endings, but I had to gather some steam to plough through the rest of the game. LMR may be a highly [b]visual[/b] novel, but it sure also is a visual [b]novel[/b]. I guess the best word to describe the writing is heavy - there's a lot to the story, and it takes a long time to get there, but the more you know, the more fascinating it gets. Still, getting all the endings took me 50 hours, with abundant use of the skipping feature - and I'm a faster-than-average reader, mind you. The game also feels slightly unpolished at times - small typos and missing full stops at the ends of lines are not uncommon. Nothing game-breaking, sure, but it still stands out in a game that has obviously seen countless hours put into its development.

In summary, LMR is a lot. A lot of amazing art, a lot of excellent music, and a lot of story. It's perhaps not the easiest visual novel to pick up even for those familiar with the genre, but if you're able to get past that, it's definitely worth the time and effort. What it does best is immersion. Everlasting Summer got me feeling nostalgic for a place I've never been to and a country that hasn't existed in my time. As I'm writing this down, having just completed the game, I'm already feeling like I will miss my little escapes into LMR's and Nikolai's Tokyo, so I guess it is fair to say that despite not reaching perfection, LMR still shines where it really counts.

144426459.review:
If only the writing was as good as the art...

The music is great and the character art, backgrounds, and CGs are beautiful. Although there are parts of the story that describe a location as a crowded but not a single person can be seen in the background. 

Of course, visuals are important for a Visual Novel, but the writing is just as important. The dialogue is bad, there is no character growth except maybe for the resolution of self vs self conflict for Catherine and the main character also coming to terms with Catherine's past decision at the end of her good ending route. The main character remains an asshole, and the dialogue remains frustrating as fuck in the other 3 "good endings" which really felt more like bad endings, and the 10 actual bad endings. Unlike other negative reviews, I don't think the problem with the writing comes from bad translations. There are very few typos and mistakes, and the spelling and grammar make sense. The real problem comes from the intentional writing. The way they tried to make the main character (player's perspective) and his high schooler friends the center of the Cold War. Only one character in the game plays music despite the game's cover and title, and the story felt like it was written with the intention of it being dark and emotionally frustrating at the cost of good dialogue, believable interpersonal relationships, character development, and consistent character personalities.

Spoilers below for a more detailed explanation:

When I started my first playthrough without looking at any guides, I was convinced that Catherine Winters is an asshole. Naturally, I tried to avoid her and I also wanted to avoid the childhood friend Himitsu who knows no boundaries. I slowly started to notice the problems with how the main character, Nikolai Anokhin is treating the people around him like Himtsu, his friends and classmates Kyosuke and Michael but I still gave Nikolai the benefit of the doubt. I thought that maybe something happened between Nikolai and his friends, making him a little more hostile towards his friends and that Nikolai will resolve his problems with his friends and become kinder to them. But I was wrong about both of those possibilities; Nikolai had no reason to be mean to his friends Kyosuke and Michael and especially not to Himitsu. 

Nikolai reveals that he has known that Himitsu has loved him for years now, but Nikolai does not give Himitsu a clear answer about whether he likes Himitsu back or not. Nikolai is afraid that he will have to grow up and stop being a baby at 18 years of age, without Himitsu coming over to cook for him, clean his house, and be like Nikolai's live-in maid for free if he tells Himitsu that he doesn't have romantic feels for Himitsu. Nikolai pretends like he is entitled to Himitsu's kindness and as if she owes him somehow despite the fact that he treats her like a necessary annoyance in life, and doesn't give her a clear answer even if you choose the routes of any of the three other heroines. But the game reveals the full extent of this abusive relationship over a long time, and you only get to know what an asshole Nikolai is once you've progressed faaar into the story. Then you start to feel bad for having thought earlier that Himitsu should have had some boundaries with Nikolai, when Nikolai is the one who should have told Himitsu to keep some boundaries, take her keys to his house, and to let her know that he's thankful for what she always does for Nikolai but that he still only loves her platonically. But Nikolai doesn't do that. He just takes her kindness for granted in every route! And if she acts like your housewife and treats you the way that Himitsu does, then she probably IS your wife! Nikolai just can't move on from the intensity he felt from his first love with Catherine and believes that love means feeling an adrenaline rush the entire time he is in the presence of someone he believes he loves. This negative review isn't just because of Himitsu, so let's get back to whose route I ended up on my first playthrough due to my first impression of the characters and the beginning of the story and what a letdown the entire route and its endings are.

At the beginning, I believed what Nikolai said about not being able to solve his perceived issues with Himitsu with words, which was wrong, Nikolai is a big baby and can't understand that most problems CAN be solved by just talking it out. He's just terrible at speaking, always blames others, and doesn't believe in the power of words and so he just hurts everyone around him by the way he treats them. He didn't have some sort of bigger issue that needed more time before he could sort them out with his friends like I believed at the time. And the way he described Catherine made me think that she was the asshole in her former relationship with Nikolai and leaving him without a goodbye and returning to the USA from Japan. At this point, Nikolai has had his first encounter with Ellie in the cafeteria and I knew that she was going to be a date-able heroine but I also knew that she's the heir to the super rich Kobayashi Corporation, so naturally I thought that the not too rich and not too poor Kagome would be the best match for Nikolai. I thought that since Kagome is the shy meek girl who gets bullied at school would like the heroism of the macho protagonist I had perceived Nikolai to be when he decides to intervene and stop the bullies from bothering Kagome at school. I believed that Kagome's cold treatment of the protagonist came from the fact that she found it hard to trust people because she got bullied at school and might have had some personal problems at home. I could not have been more wrong. Kagome turns out to be a complete sociopath as the bullying escalates and either the bullies or Kobayashi Corp or one of the intelligence agencies from the poorly written political espionage subplots set Kagome's family restaurant and house on fire after her dad is kidnapped, presumably by the Kobayashi Corporation that he used to work for. And conveniently enough, Kobayashi Ellie goes to the same elite high school as Kagome and Nikolai! In Kagome's route, Ellie is kidnapped and the KGB is proud of Nikolai for doing so but Nikolai believes that someone else has kidnapped Ellie and it definitely isn't Kagome!! But it turns out that Kagome WAS the one who kidnapped Ellie and she seems to have a personal grudge against Ellie and neither Nikolai or Ellie know why, as Kagome's previous and current treatment of Ellie seems to extreme for just having a hostage valuable to Kobayashi Corp as leverage for releasing Kagome's father. This isn't even the worst part. If you take Ellie's route, Ellie's bully friends get kidnapped and killed, all 8 of them in one night. The police and everyone first suspect Kagome, but the police releases Kagome (I will explain why later) but it is still heavily implied that Kagome was the one who did it. After some pointless plotting and seeing that Kobayashi Corp won't give in to their demands to release Kagome's father and when they find Ellie in the warehouse where she was tied up by Kagome, she escapes to the countryside with Nikolai for a while and they work hard jobs with little pay and pretend like life is normal. One day when Himitsu spots them in the village since it's close to her grandma's house, Kagome and the MC decide that they need to return to Tokyo as they've been found out anyway. NOW is the time when Kagome admits that she's the child of Kobayashi Jun's illegitimate daughter and this whole problem could have been solved from the beginning! She could have just tried to convince her grandfather, the head of Kobayashi Corp, to release her father instead of all this pointless bullshit "plot" the writers forced into the story to waste everyone's time and ruin out emotional investment because Kagome turns out to be a self-serving sociopath and her good ending brings no joy.

Честно признаться, я не ожидал ничего особенного от игры. Частично видел на стримах прохождение рута то ли Химицу, то ли Кетрин, где ГГ вёл себя как тряпка что с одной, что с другой, и меня это как-то не заинтересовало.
Но в обзорных роликах по игре ещё в прошлом году я видел кое-кого ещё... А именно девушку с каштановыми волосами, старосту класса, где кое-как учится ГГ. Что-то в тех обрывках фраз от этой девушки из роликов меня привлекло. Ну а то, что ГГ, судя по всему, старательно избегал её, только подогрело мой интерес.

И вот, когда наконец появились время и желание, я купил игру с намерением пройти рут Кагомэ. Мне всегда "везло" по жизни со старостами, в БЛ первые две открытые концовки были плохими, так что наиболее вероятным исходом мне виделась какая-нибудь плохая концовка и здесь.
Чтобы сделать игру максимально интересной, я принял для себя правило делать каждый выбор только один раз, соответственно не загружаться и не смотреть подсказки.

Первые несколько игровых дней ничего особенно интересного не происходило. ГГ вёл себя по-идиотски и непоследовательно, в одних сценал думал одно, в других совершенно другое. Прогуливал школу и напивался. Я даже не был уверен, что выйду на рут Кагомэ, но в тех выборах, которые нужно было делать чуть ли не наугад, я каким-то чудом попадал на нужные сцены.
Постепенно картина стала меняться - шпионские игры на заднем плане (я воспринимал эту сюжетную линию исключительно как фоновую) заставили ГГ поднапрячься. Но это всё были сущие мелочи по сравнию с...

Кагомэ, Кагомэ, Кагомэ. С ней было буквально ультра-тяжело. Упорная, своенравная, скрытная... На фоне принятых правил игры степень сложности в некоторых моментах была настолько высока, что я пару раз чуть не сорвался, чтобы посмотреть, к чему приведёт другой вариант выбора. Но у меня хватило сил сдержаться, да и это было бы для меня непростительно.
К этому моменту игра уже однозначно заработала положительный отзыв за датфил и за то, что удалось вжиться в образ ГГ, но где-то впереди меня всё ещё ждал финал.
Удалось немного успокоиться тем, что я изначально рассчитывал на плохую концовку. Я продолжил играть и гнуть свою линию, делая каждый выбор только раз. Впрочем, их уже практически не осталось, и оставалось рассчитывать, что мои предыдущие выборы были, скажем так, правильными.

До финала я дошёл морально измотанным, честным перед собой и с призрачной надеждой, что ещё есть шанс. В итоге... а впрочем, это уже неважно.

Один этот рут стоит всей игры. Ритан, ты лучший

140415322.review:
I went into this game expecting something similar to Everlasting Summer. However, after reaching 100% completion, what I got was surprisingly different for both better and worse.

The good:
-Art is absolutely phenomenal and well made in every scene
-Animations for both the characters and backgrounds are great and sometimes really help to add emotion to some scenes
-Music is surprisingly good and I'd consider it even better than Everlasting Summer
-I really enjoyed two of the routes presented from start to finish for different reasons [spoiler] Ellie's was my favourite due to the various events which occur, her sweet nature and serious personal problems which Nikolai helps to solve in her good ending. Kagome's route starts out as perhaps a bit annoying, but it's clear from the start she has much more going on than it first seems. She has far more dramatic events which are better if you prefer a serious story from start to finish. [/spoiler]

The bad:
-Some of the routes feel too long and padded with no choices presented to the player for a long time [spoiler] Catherine's route is especially bad when it comes to this. [/spoiler]  This truly does hurt the pacing and makes the game feel like a slog sometimes
-I played this game in English and the translation is rough. A few lines are shockingly bad and haven't been fixed even months after release which is astounding. I understand that this game has a lot of dialogue, but surely these errors could've been fixed by now
-Two of the other routes range from mediocre to bad and I wouldn't recommend them to anyone [spoiler] While Himitsu has a lot of stuff happen in the end, it's not enough to save how utterly generic the beginning and middle are. Her route mostly feels like a boring slice of life story which we've seen a thousand times by now. However, her path is nothing when compared to how terrible Catherine is. Besides the pacing issues, she is annoying and toxic from start to finish and never really changes. I couldn't wait to finish all her endings and never return due to how bad she is. [/spoiler]

Overall, I would recommend this game to fans of Everlasting Summer even at its current price due to how much effort has been put on display with the art, music and long story with some truly emotional moments. However, if you're just a fan of visual novels or a newcomer, I'd recommend picking this game up on discount.

Good Visual Novel.

137345763.review:
This game is supposed to be THE successor to "Everlasting Summer". But these games are comparable only to an extent, While Everlasting Summer was an escapist-eroge fantasy of days past with a hope to turn the life around, LMR is a more realistic light-novel with crime elements and no graphically sexual content.
You get to choose four girls and four "good endings" as well as TWO bad endings with each character. These are more bad endings than in Everlasting Summer but none of them seem to be as bad as the one with Lena. They are much more grounded and in these instances you can see the evolution of the scriptwriter. In other instances this evolution is not so clear... One scene was particularly telling for me, it's a scene where the protagonist must run away from his pursuers and he starts to philosophise about running and what it means etc. utter bullshit that no sane person who is running away in a stressful situation would ask himself.
Another minus is the lack of diversity of scenes/backgrounds. After so many years of development (and I was amongst the first ones to sponsor this development) the creators were not able to aquire enough backgrounds for varied storys. Therefore the characters tend to return to the very same places and streets with different dialogues.
The best parts of this game are the music, the writing and the early (qualitative) graphics that were also present in the early demo. The completed game had rather sub-par graphics.
Don't get me wrong: I still love this game, But I've waited so long only to become a second-class product from a team who's writer is narcistically in love with his own texts... it had so much more potential...

137340732.review:
[h1]TL;DR[/h1]

10/10: The graphics, story, and characters all make for a top tier visual novel, and the perfect score is justified even if there's more elements of a spy technothriller than there is love, money, or rock 'n' roll!

[h1]Overview[/h1]

Can you believe ol' Il Pallino was never sought out to officially review a visual novel? The important thing to know is that the story of [i]Love, Money, Rock'n'Roll[/i] (sic) starts in the year 1987 about a Soviet boy named Nikolai who had fallen in love with a girl named Katya only to have to break up due to Nikolai's family relocating to Japan after Nikolai's father lands a research job at a multinational corporation. Nikolai's parents die in an auto accident which leaves Nikolai orphaned but with a home and a decent amount of money, Katya ends up returning to Nikolai's life, only for other girls to appear in Nikolai's life on top of the proverbial "lifelong friend" in Nikolai's neighbor. One of the other girls at Nikolai's school has her father mysteriously vanish, and enlists in Nikolai's help finding out what happened to the father which makes Nikolai question the "accidental" circumstances in which his parents died. All the while, Nikolai returns to his old interest in playing the bass, only to discover that all of the female students that Nikolai has encountered also share an interest for music. (But for some strange reason, neither of the two male classmates of Nikolai are interested in music.)

[h1]Graphics and Sound[/h1]

Normally the most important aspect about the graphics, is that the girls all average an 8.98 on the Kawaii-O-Meter, and one of the background scenes even contains movement. (Something never seen before, but [i]Escalation![/i] doesn't count!) Another nice thing about the graphics is that the girls do not keep the same facial expression through scenes, and regardless if a scene is unique or a stock scene, there is movement to be had, and not just blinking eyes.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2967490354

While there's little sound to speak of, the developers aced it with the soundtrack. The music doesn't always play, which is good, because ol' Il Pallino would have long since muted the music. Instead, music plays at more dramatic moments in the game, and each tune is both perfect sounding and perfectly fits the mood of the situation. There's even a concert scene which contains vocals that add to the feeling that a concert is being witnessed.

[h1]Positives and Negatives[/h1]

The characters are all realistic, and even more realistic than what can be encountered in slice of life visual novels. This must be good for people who love it "real," but everyone is also too flawed of a human being to really feel likable. (Much less lovable.) Interesting? Yes. Intriguing? Absolutely... Just not possible for many players to develop an attachment to outside of looks. (I suppose it is realistic in the sense that many women IRL have more interesting looks than personalities.)

Apart from the title missing the word "and" in it, the title does feel misleading. But why sex up an already amazing story? [i]Love, Money, Rock'n'Roll[/i] isn't a trashy visual novel by any means, and nobody would have purchased the game expecting any portion of the visual novel to be a technothriller.

Unlike other visual novels, [i]Love, Money, Rock'n'Roll[/i] provides help for any players who may be lacking knowledge of various cultures, and need the clue-by-four for explanations about things like Bastille Day in France and ryumachnoyas, and when available, the player can click on the text to receive a description... So while being as intelligent as any good slice of life visual novel, the player can play [i]Love, Money, Rock'n'Roll[/i] and truly learn something!

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2967491631

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

[i]Love, Money, Rock'n'Roll[/i] is a strong buy, and there's even achievements and trading cards. (The thing which drives hardcore gamers to Steam in the first place.) Not only is this game SFW, but it isn't even trashy so Steam users can gift this visual novel to those few strange people who would rather enjoy enjoy a visual novel without sex and nudity!

[h1]The honest word of Il Pallino... OR ELSE![/h1]

[quote]Follow our curator page, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/7871885/]OCG-Curations[/url], if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/quote]

Seemed interesting, had good reviews, honestly, I am utterly disappointed. I'm fine with dramatic VNs, I've played my fair share, I've played through Clannad and After Story numerous times, I've played a decent amount of them, but this one pissed me off.

First off, the good things: translation is pretty good given its Russian, noticed tiny missing words or slightly incorrect word usage but nothing that made it difficult to read, it wasn't common. Also music isn't bad, but its really grating once you hear the same tracks over and over again, (and its a multi-choice romance VN, you're gonna replay this at least 4 times, even just 2 times ruined the soundtrack) I guess I shouldn't have expected much from a VN but I was expecting something a bit more rock for something with Rock'n'Roll in the name. (especially when its alluding to the classic trope of Sex, Drugs, and Rock'n'Roll) Arts pretty good, its clean and unique without being cheesy or grating. Animations were nice but seemed completely unnecessary, their disconnect from what they're actually doing was more distracting then it should've been. Dialogue wasn't bad for the most part. UI is clean if but strange to be done in such a way. The writing is also enticing when it makes sense. That's about all the good stuff I can think of.

Now for the frustrating and bad:

Foremost deceptive name for someone who understands the allusion of the name, I had a complete false pretense of what this game had going for it and the synopsis was next to useless.

If you believe this is a story about music at all, and for which the banner claims that as the case, you're wrong and you were scammed. Only one of the routes includes any interest in music at all.

As is usual with a bunch of low rate VNs, the decisions don't make any logical sense and you need to use a guide or a diagram to traverse each route properly. This is especially bad because all the good endings require very specific decisions which many don't even seem related and which make no semantic nor narrative sense to contribute to said ending.

And now lets get to a big elephant in the room, and spoiler warning for the game, but Himitsu (the childhood friend archetype) has been stabbing the MC in the back from the start and Kogame is a literal sociopath. Both of their paths are pretty frustrating in light of these facts. For Himitsu, it really does start to feel like she was merely spying on the MC in light of what the story gives you instead of actually caring about him, only for the story to forget what it said and move on as if she only did something extremely minor. As for Kogame, she kidnaps Ellie forcing the MC into a position where he can't refuse to help her. And guess what happens if you do? The MC is murdered by Ellie's grandfather. WHY?!?!? Out of every single element of the goddamn story, this was the thing that completely destroyed my suspension of disbelief, which was starting to get on thin ice for how often the translation, being totally proficient in what it was saying disagreed with the tone and feelings of the characters and their behavior, you think that despite everything that you actively releasing someone from rope ties after being kidnapped in a warehouse, after said kidnapped character asked you to release her and pleaded with you, you would goddamn think that minimally Kogame would be the one killed. I'm sorry but what the actual hell is wrong with you? Are Russians this so goddamn braindead they believe these sequence of events make any goddamn sense? I swear to God after that fiasco and forcing the MC to participate in kidnapping and then constantly torturing him over it and then the goddamn kidnapping girl whining and complaining that you're somehow in the wrong, I can't forgive this crap tier story for this. I wasn't even invested in finishing the story because it doesn't matter what more you had to say, you jumped the goddamn shark when you justified kidnapping someone innocent and drag innocent people into your affairs that will get them killed. The story never points out how evil this is and the MC has to just go through with it, the more I played this part the more angry and depressed it made me, I just wanted to stop. I honestly want a refund over this trash, too bad visual novels fall outside the realm of Steam's refund policy, nothing was worth this, I don't care about the positives, just this entire branch that goes on for at least a few hours was so horrifically stupid I can't stand even opening this game again. And I'm willing to bet the railroading, maybe not being as bad in the other branches I haven't played, they likely are just as jarring, even if not as frustrating, as this. How the hell do you even translate the story so well and produce complete nonsense thinking? Its supposed to be the opposite way around. By the end of the narrative I was wishing I could've personally killed Kogame.

135162204.review:
Where to begin, where to begin...

Firstly, the music was 10/10, the animations were amazing and unique, from the sprite to even the backgrounds. How immersive!
I resolutely played my first round without changing my choices, even if I regretted them immediately... And I did. I got Kagome Bad End #1 for my first play-through. Despite that, the story was engaging, thrilling, infuriating, irritating, emotional, and a bunch of other things. I actually felt the weight of my emotions after receiving my ending. I'll be slowly collecting all the other endings as well, make no mistake about that. This novel is the best I ever played, period.

But regrettably, that doesn't mean it is without some flaws, even if they're minor. Firstly, the MC: Nikolai. What wreck. Super impulsive, emotional, self-destructive, rude, and just annoying at times with his self-hatred and self-pity. 
The other characters also have their things: Himitsu is clingy (though I don't mind that. She's cute). Catherine is just... Mystery. Kagome is just irritatingly stubborn, whether or not you get a good or bad end. And Ellie [spoiler] seemingly sent me to my death [/spoiler] for who-knows-why so I'll need convincing that she's a good character.

Then the choices, for such a large novel, felt a little far and few in between. At times, it felt like there where choices where none was warranted and no choices when there should have been. But that said, the choices change the direction of the novel drastically, with your very first choice seemingly sending you down one or another set of 7 endings each.
There are a few spelling mistakes here and there but nothing that will ruin the tone of the sentence or conversation. Just throws a little lol.

All that said, LMRnR is a solid 10/10 for me, even with its flaws. Worth every cent, every minute, and every session.
P.S. if you plan on sitting through the credits for the Patience achievement, be prepared to sit through about 1 hour and 40 minutes of credits (I timed it) you were warned. Good luck :-)

EDIT: the more I play, the more I think the store page should include warnings for references the bedroom dance, drug usage, betrayal, murder, and heart-break

135070725.review:
This will be long, so here is the short version:
Buy, play, feel. You will be in for a ride.

Now, on to the real, long version of my review...

I have never played visual novels that much. When I found out about Love, Money, Rock'n Roll, it wasn't even because I was looking for a new game to play, but because I was looking up certain things about the Unity Game Engine and wandered off and came across an article about how the environment visuals of Love, Money, Rock'n Roll made. The techniques were interesting so I took note. When it came out, I wasn't in any hurry to play it and kept dragging my feet. But here I am. 

Love, Money, Rock'n Roll had been an emotional roller coaster for me. I was interested in Japan, in the techniques used in the making of the game, the setting sounded interesting enough, but what I experienced far outmatched my expectations. 

We play as our protagonist, Nikolai, at the first real important turning point of his/our life, making decisions for himself/ourselves in the world of 80s Japan, our decisions leading us down paths we least expect. The dangers, conflicts, happy and sad moments we experience throughout the story felt all very new, unique and deeply touching. I found myself feeling what Nikolai would have felt, became excited at the prospect of waking up to a good day, looking forward to spending time with people we cared about, felt devastated at the misfortunes and wrong decisions we made and where those decisions brought us. The way this novel handled human relationships felt so different, inartificial, for some reason.

Then there is the music. Every single moment in the game that I was brought to emotional extremes, the music joined in, enveloped my emotions, brought them to new heights. I found myself smiling silly when silly or happy things happened, relieved that things were okay. I sighed in relief when we dodged a sticky situation, or the storm has passed. When things went downhill and we were in the deepest parts of hell, I felt my limbs go numb, my heart clench hard. I even found myself having to take some breaks at certain points to not actually feint. The way the entire OST fit the time period, the place the story was set in, and most importantly, the moments they empowered, was amazing. I have found a good many songs I would listen to from today onward.

I can count with my hand the number of content that made me feel the things Love, Money, Rock'n Roll made me feel, Nikolai, Kyousuke, Kagome, Ellie, Michael, Himitsu, Catherine, their lives, their experiences, their interactions, feelings and conflicts. It all felt so unreasonable, kind, selfish, sincere at the same time.

It has been a very long review again, I feel like rambling at this point. 
So, for anyone who is still reading my humble opinion on this game, I would strongly recommend them to buy and try putting themselves in the shoes of Nikolai Anokhin, and for a short while, experience this turbulent period of his life together with him and his friends. Let me tell you though, you are in for a ride.

P.S. I am amazed I managed not give a single spoiler. I hope I didn't. Right? Right?!

133124609.review:
"Stepping back thinking, in another life, we are happy together."

After "Everlasting Summer" the guys at Soviet Games could have published a shopping list, and I would have been interested - and probably entertained too :) There is just something about a bunch of professionals coming together and making magic. I also think that the Russian perspective to storytelling, brings a fresh look and feel to visual novels, which I absolutely adore. It's just ...darker..edgier. And looking back at all the backers (yes, I got the achievement for watching to the end), I'm not the only one who feels this way.

This story is full of noir themes, and philosophy, almost Tolstoy-ish at times (and that is the highest praise I can give here) invoking humour, but also terrible pain and anguish when it goes to almost unimaginable places of despair. For example at one point where (I think in the Kagome arc - which was one of my favourites) refers to the 'dark day', when you literally have to run away from your normal life, leave everything behind that you know and love, with no money and just the clothes on your back, to get to safety. This was mind blowing and such an eye opener for us who lives with modern day luxuries.

I adored the 80s setting, references and the music and it was so fitting with the vhs menus and game forwards and rewinds. The 80s was also a time where this spy drama is set, when you were only as strong as your intelligence. When the CIA, and especially the KGB were scarier than the boogeyman. Kind of difficult to imagine these days with our free flowing information on the internet. I also want to send a big thank you and shout out for[spoiler] the little Easter egg with the rock goddess Alisa in front of the music club[/spoiler] it brought back so many good Pioneer camp memories for me, thank you :) 

PROS: It's kind of harder this time to pick a favourite lady in my opinion. You have the best friend and girl next door, you have the ex girlfriend from a foreign country, you have the popular girl and rock star and you have the quiet mysterious one. All solid choices. This left me with the need to play all the good endings for the 4 main ladies, so it ticked the replay-ability box and then some. More is always better, I personally would have loved and arc where we get to romance and interrogate the beautiful Irina as well, alas, perhaps for the future :) At the time of this review, I was not yet done with all of the endings, feeling the need to pace myself after all the emotional highs and lows. Going on to the darker endings, well, I'll only advise for those who are ready for it. But do brace yourself, it's ruff.

CONS: Finally I do want to make a point about the lack of carnality, yes you read that right, lack of lusty adult scenes that was so elegantly used in your previous game. I get the reasons for it, your selling platform having a fit about school uniforms and hanky panky. You have frequent alcohol references, violence, but giving and showing love scenes is still taboo? Grow up people, we want to make our own decisions on our entertainment. You do no not need to nanny us, we are all adults. And this is an adult novel in all other ways. I also understand there was some kind of patch for the Russian version, but no working one (at the time of this review) for the English version. Will keep an eye on this. Real life, and real 18 year olds do drink and have sex, even if you want to stick your head in the sand about it. Thank you for the censorship, not. Okay, glad I got that of the chest :) 

Also with hind-site, a not so much likeable main character, with little development and personal growth as a person. An orphan who is stuck in his ways. But again, not unbelievable as a character. Some commentators have mentioned 'hysterics' at some arcs, which I can agree with partially, but again, how would you generate some drama otherwise? Did you grow up in the 80s, did you understand the KGB, are you an orphan who is being hunted, etc? If not, check your commentary.

It is a very good visual novel, with beautiful music that was put together with love, money and rock 'n roll. Kinda feel that's what the world also needs more of... 9.5/10

After the for me disappointing  Everlasting Summer, this was a pleasantly cruel ride.
The writing overall is exellent, the music is perfectly matched and the visuals are top notch.
Characters also show a lot more depth than the previous outing.

Things to nitpick about are:

- "Inconsistent" MC. I feel like, that depending on which route you take, you either need to deal with a lovesick ahole that can't decide, or a more well rounded or maybe driven/focused MC. Could also be by design, but it made one branch less enjoyable to go through.

- Not all Endings received equal treatment. While Ellie's and Kagome's good Endings gave a glimps into future years, Catherine's felt abrupt and incomplete. Himitsu's didn't have an outlook as well, but at least had a better conclusion that left nothing open.

- Text should have gotten 1 or 2 more correction passes. It doesn't distract from what they want to get across, but you too often notice the mistakes. Even as a non native speaker.


Overall I highly recommend it with one warning for completionists:
Don't go for a back to back bad ending clear. Some routes will break you.

130152998.review:
CONTAINS SPOILERS: As of now Ive done three endings, one of himitsus bad endings (due to blind first playthrough), himitsu's good ending and ellies ""GOOD"" ending. I dont think I can do catherines or Kagome's routes. I can parrot the same criticism as everyone, Nikolai is an asshole, hes fatalist to a stupid detriment, hes a bipolar schizophrenic. Hes literally me FR!
Not every MC is going to be a stoic, 99% of the time silent guy. Think when your playing a game like Witcher, You are roleplaying but you are not role playing a character *you* made, you have to play the role of Geralt whether you really like it or not. So while it at times it can be frustrating that he is going against how I want a situation to play out, thats just how it has to be. Now the solution to that is to have more and more choices, which leads to more and more divergences and that makes it even harder to decide how each ending should play out if all these intermediary choices should really have an effect or not. So I am fine with how Nikolai acts, except for in ellies ""Good"" Ending, I did not time it but after making the final choice and getting the ending felt like almost an hour and a half while I just have to watch an absolute spiral of despair that I couldnt have a choice in.

I do not like catherine, and I do not like her implementation into Himitsu's ending making unavoidable problems that could be very easily solved by either a slap or making it very clear for her to dissappear. Other than that, the writing of Himitsu's story is beautifully tragic. I want to thank the writers that came up with her route as while it felt quite short it was a perfect roller coaster of emotions that ended very happily.

When it came to Ellie's route I did not think it would be nearly as depressing as Himitsu's was mainly due to that shes the only one of the girls whos steam trading card wasnt them crying or being angry. I was wrong! How I was wrong! Im from a working class family so stories of some commoner guy winning the heart of an upper class girl and breaking class boundaries always capture my heart in a special way, thats what I thought this would be. It reminded me of the song "Common People" in the beginning showing a girl who's used to servants waiting on her without the need to ever go to stores and the like. Throw in a dash of cocaine a couple hours later and you realize the rock star princess that you loved is an addict and no matter how much you try she just does not listen. Ending up with an overdosed ellie, and from here is where you are locked onto rails as she gets mad at *you* for trying to get her to stop with the cocaine, followed by continued misunderstanding perpetrated by Kagome. I have probably done a very bad job explaining the course of events, it is mainly because the series of events mirrors something very closely that happened in my own life, so that might bias me to think the way they turn into a good ending was extremely contrived and rushed to just make the big concert happen.

Overall 8/10 Just dont do ellies route

130019538.review:
Love, Money, Rock'n'Roll a pesar de ser un juego sólido, ha resultado ser una decepción en muchos aspectos. Lo llevo esperando desde que terminé Everlasting Summer hace muchos años pero hasta ahora no he podido jugar a este.

¿Lo he disfrutado? La respuesta es: a ratos. Este juego tiene muchísimo relleno y muchísimas cosas innecesarias que tienen más importancia de la que debería. Está diseñado como un dating sim de toda la vida con sus rutas y sus cosas pero al final eso es más secundario que otra cosa y la subtrama de espías y conspiraciones y politiqueo acaba tomando el primer plano y la verdad es que lo arruina todo porque es innecesariamente compleja, no resuelven nada y no es interesante en absoluto.

Voy a ir punto por punto empezando por las cosas que sí me han gustado:

+ Visualmente el juego es una delicia. Los fondos se sienten vivos, muchos de ellos animados, con muy buena calidad y de verdad que son preciosos en su mayoría. Normalmente es algo que se suele obviar en otros juegos al ser considerado más secundario, pero en este juego le han dado un protagonismo importante y se agradece. También hay muchos personajes escondidos en los fondos tanto de cultura popular como Big Floppa como otros de juegos como Everlasting Summer, Ace Attorney o Steins;Gate que aunque no interactuan en el juego, verlos de fondo si los reconoces es agradable.

+ Relacionado con lo de arriba, los personajes se sienten vivos. Transiciones fluidas de animaciones que se agradecen, y lo que es verdaderamente curioso es que hay una cantidad absurda de personajes. No entiendo si son ideas descartadas o qué, pero el que hayan hecho modelos para personajes que salen literalmente en una escena con sus animaciones y todo me parece increible por el hecho de que crea más inmersión, pero a la vez te deja con la intriga de por qué ese personaje existe si sólo sale en una escena y no lo vamos a conocer más. ¿Quizá una posible secuela o un DLC? seria interesante la verdad.

+ La música es el otro punto fuerte del juego. Igual que con los fondos y los personajes, el apartado artístico es el que mejor cuidado está con diferencia. La banda sonora es increiblemente extensa y buena. No soy muy de comprar bandas sonoras pero si un juego se lo merece, es este.

+ Estética de los 80: Habrá a quien le guste y a quien no, pero la nostalgia pega fuerte. Y un juego basado en los 80 con un apartado artístico tan bueno es una delicia aún mejor.

* Personajes principales: Sin entrar en spoilers grandes, hay cuatro rutas con cuatro chicas diferentes. Las rutas son de una calidad variada, en mi opinión sólo dos considero que merezcan la pena, el resto tienen demasiado relleno. Por suerte, las chicas son en su mayoría buenos personajes. No se aferran en exceso a estereotipos y te van a dar alguna sorpresa que otra. Y otra cosa que me gusta es que no son predecibles en absoluto, y que todas están un poco mal de la cabeza a su manera lo cual las hace sentir más reales y menos planas en el sentido de aferrarse a su estereotipo hasta la muerte. Kagome my beloved <3

+ Trivia y datos curiosos tanto de la URSS como de Japón: Para los que no estén muy metidos en cultura japonesa o rusa, el juego marca en azul toda frase o palabra que puede no entenderse para lectores de fuera, lo cual se agradece mucho (o redundante según el conocimiento que tengas), pero en general se agradece.

+- No sé si considerarlo malo o bueno, pero el juego no tiene nada excesivamente turbio, raro o creepy como sí pasaba en Everlasting Summer y me ha hecho estar en guardia todo el rato para nada. Sí que es verdad que echaba de menos algún giro argumental turbio, que aunque los hay no les dan la importancia que merecen.

Dicho esto, vamos con lo malo, que no es poco:

- El guión: Es un desastre en todos los sentidos. El juego intenta ser un simulador de citas en los 80 con una subtrama de espías y conspiraciones a gran escala, pero resulta ser todo lo contrario. El romance pasa a un segundo plano y a menudo se siente hasta forzado. Se podría entender si la ''subtrama'' fuese interesante pero no lo es. Es un auténtico caos de literalmente cuatro facciones con intereses difusos que se están tirando de los pelos todo el rato y que el protagonista está en el medio un poco porque sí. Al principio puede ser interesante pero después te das cuenta que no te van a resolver nada. Parece que vas a descubrir algo, pero no. Y siempre es igual. No hace falta ser un genio escribiendo misterio para saber que si no le das al lector información con cuentagotas pierde el interés en el misterio.

Personajes que actúan de formas que no tienen sentido, intereses que se contradicen, agujeros argumentales... Además de que el inicio del juego es horriblemente lento por esto mismo, mucha intriga al principio pero después nada, son pesados que existen para alargar el juego de forma artificial, junto a los monólogos incesantes del protagonista que de nuevo engordan la duración del juego. Finales repentinos e insulsos. Reconozco algunos que están bien, pero otros es como ''ah, pues vale''. Acaban y te quedas igual porque no hay sensación de clímax, de resolución de conflictos, de nada. Simplemente acaba, normalmente gracias al archiconocido recurso del deus ex machina que yo personalmente odio.

- Skip lento: Los finales malos son una lotería, algunos son pochos y otros son incluso mejores que otras rutas enteras. Pero para llegar ahí, hay que releer texto haciendo elecciones diferentes y aquí el skip es necesario en cualquier novela visual con finales múltiples (o una flowchart vendría genial) pero aquí es absurdamente lenta, por el hecho de que se detiene cada vez que los personajes hacen una animación o sea que te puedes llevar un buen rato. A mi incluso se me rompió el skip en cierta ruta y tuve que estar pasando manualmente durante una hora contenido que ya había visto, o sea que no mola nada y lo que hace es arruinar la experiencia y te obliga a que uses guías salvo que seas un masoquista.

- Protagonista. Hay dos tipos de protagonistas en las novelas visuales: El self-insert con cero personalidad para que el lector se sienta identificado, o el que intenta romper esos esquemas pero el 99% del tiempo acaba siendo un idiota insufrible. Bueno, el segundo caso es nuestro NIkolai. Es un tío increíblemente tóxico, trata a sus amigos fatal, insulta a la más mínima aunque le hablen de buenas, es un borracho y un penas y encima es un mentiroso compulsivo. Una joyita de tío, vaya. Y la historia hubiese sido realmente sencilla si dejase de ocultar cosas y mentir a todo el mundo por razones desconocidas. La mitad de las conversaciones del juego acaban mal y casi siempre es culpa del protagonista que como digo es un impresentable, es imposible identificarse con una persona así.

- Esto es algo menor, pero el arte oficial en el que salen las cuatro chicas en una banda, no aparece en ningún lugar ni momento del juego, lo digo por el que espere una novela visual alrededor de la música. Sólo hay una ruta en la que participas en una banda y es con un personaje nada más, y como le pasa al resto de las rutas pasa a un segundo plano por la aburrida subtrama de espías.

- Por último, entiendo que es una novela visual grande, pero hay una cantidad enorme de faltas de ortografía, bugs visuales, personajes diciendo frases que no le tocan y movidas así que por desgracia son bastante recurrentes y sacan un poco de la experiencia. No sé si en ruso es igual pero la traducción al ingles tiene muchos errores. Se deja entender, pero a poco que prestes algo de atención te das cuenta de que es un desastre.

- Créditos de 2 horas: En serio, poner un logro por ver los créditos que duran casi dos horas me parece un pasote. por muchas gracias que les quieras dar a los que te han apoyado económicamente, ni la gente que ha pagado se va a ver dos horas de nombres para ver el suyo.

Me he quedado sin espacio, lo cual es una pena, quería decir más. Un saludo.

129017365.review:
First off, a disclaimer. I suppose anyone who has read most or all of Everlasting Summer (their previous title) should already be able to figure this out, but when this story ends bad, it can end *very* bad. I just finished my first ending yesterday, and it's probably going to be haunting me for the next few days (and it isn't even the end, but some of the stuff that leads up to it that is probably also in the good ending). Lena bad end is comparable.

Additionally, this title really should have content warnings comparable to those in DDLC, though I suppose doing that sort of thing is a purely American thing. So for those of you who might otherwise stumble across something you'd rather not have read: Content warning: Drug use, mass murder, suicide. Also sex, but I'm pretty sure you're here for that.

Finally, Nikolai is at least as bad as Seymon when it comes to social ineptitude and unjustifiable hostility. And unlike Seymon, he isn't surrounded by girls who can heal him; they can barely take care of themselves. This is not a fun happy romance story. Shit gets real.

And that's what it comes down to: this story provides a very realistic portrayal of the uglier side of life. Yes, I got frustrated with Nikolai's behavior, but the fact is I've known guys like him, and at times, I've been guys like him. There were times I nearly screamed with frustration at Nikolai's latest idiocy... then remembered that I'd done something similar in the past. I wasn't as bad, but I can definitely relate. If you think of yourself as a socially well adjusted, reasonably popular, effective person who'd rather have nothing to do with "that guy", you're probably not going to like this story, because Nikolai is very much "that guy".

All this being said, everything about this VN is story is fantastic. The art, in both conception and implementation, is top notch, and a more than substantial improvement over Everlasting Summer. The soundtrack is good, though the jury is out on that until I've had a few more playthroughs to let it sink in. And the writing is very good, and less awkwardly phrased than it was in Everlasting Summer (where I wasn't sure if the problem was the original script or the translation). I enjoyed the earlier parts, the middle parts were super stressful, and the end... well, I got a bad end, but I can't help but think that after all that, a good end would be quite rewarding.

I can't start this review without first mentioning Everlasting Summer. Soviet Games really caught lightning in a bottle with that game and it was free! It was so good that I actually kind of felt like I ripped the developers off by not paying for the thing. I decided right then that if these guys put out a paid release I was going to buy it regardless of what the game was. That's why when the trailer dropped for Love, Money, Rock'n'Roll I added it to my wishlist right away.

It was a long wait before the release of this game and I have to tell you that when I played it for the first time I was kind of disappointed. I strongly disliked one of the heroines Catherine and the way she interjects herself into Himitsu's storyline. Normally if you don't like a character in this sort of game you can just ignore them until they go away but not in this case. It led to several situations where I wished I could talk for the main character and just tell her to go away. 

I was also a bit disappointed that this game doesn't have any weird hidden routs like Everlasting Summer did. When I first played I was all oh sure it says four heroines but there is probably some weird hidden routs where you save Japan from Godzilla or I don't know something. After all we had been waiting years for this thing there are probably a few surprises but nope, what you see is what you get as far as I can tell. 

All of this doesn't mean Love, Money, Rock'n'Roll is a bad game. It isn't, it's solid, but the game isn't great either. I'm looking forward to the next game from Soviet Games. I'll be buying it day one, but I won't be expecting another Everlasting Summer. There can be only one.

127893747.review:
I've bought the game when it released, playing it non stop until getting all the good endings.. well.. as non-stop as I could, because most of the time after finishing my first 2 routes I just had no desire to play. I felt so saturated by this VN that I couldn't even bring myself to write a review until now, 4 months later.

As others have pointed out, the OST and the visuals are amazing, the technical aspects, like the animated characters and background, are also top notch.. everything is good.. but the writing.

To extend on that, it isn't exactly bad in a few specific things, some characters were well written, and even the the most criticized character, Nikolai, wasn't all that bad either (most of the time). The biggest problem IMO is how long anything and everything took to happen, or just how dragged out things get, I truly feel that 5-6 hours of each route could easily be cut out and it wouldn't change anything, if anything it'd add to the game. There just seems to be so much filler after the "middle" point of the story that you start feeling *tired* of reading what's pretty much nothing over and over, just waiting for *something* to happen. (I never even went back to 100% the game after getting the good endings, just couldn't bring myself to suffer through so much text just to get a few bad endings and achievements)

And I'm not trying to be mean here but sometimes I just had a feeling that, whoever wrote the story just thought too highly of themselves as a writer and that whatever they came up with would be outstanding and, "being a writer" they knew exactly what they were doing. I got this feeling over and over for 2 reasons, first being for how dragged out the story felt and second for [spoiler]how in one of the endings, Nikolai himself says "As a writer myself, that's what I would do" or something like that[/spoiler], and yes not really a good reason but it was at that moment that I started having this feeling.

I had been waiting for years for this game to be released, had high expectations because of how good Everlasting Summer was story-wise, but ended up being disappointed by the only thing I thought I wouldn't be: the writing.

126603562.review:
Soo, let's start with the good things this game has:
1. Music is outstanding
2. Visual style does a very beatiful representation 80-90's Japan
3. character art is on point and the sprites are animated better than I have seen in any other VN. 

Overall, [b]everything[/b] the player sees and hears [u]when not looking at the big box with letters[/u] is exceptionally atmospheric and a clear win of development team. Props where it is due.

However this is a visual novel, and thus its main aspect is a story. Previous release of Soviet Games - Everlasting Summer - actually had one, which was not bad. Taken the clustefuck which was the development process of that game, authors have delivered something, which was remotely believable. It was nothing special, definetly not he best writing I have seen, but it was at least at moderate to good level, even showing some writing talent. Thus one could have expected, that the same studio, having the experience with writing big branching plots in ES, will deliver something att least on par with their previous release. And, one last Kudos, they partially succeeded. The story in itself is more believable and collected and the secondary characters including the four main girls are actual personalities. I will however remark here, that the story is a LOT shorter than the one of ES and features a lot less choices both in absolute count and in the density. Player will have at most less than [spoiler]30[/spoiler] choices depending on the path.

And now we are approaching my biggest point of critique and an absolute deal breaker for this otherwise not bad game - the protagonist Nikolai. Directly from the start he is presented as a childish (this one is the sole understandable trait, given his age), selfish, whiny, unjustifiably aggrressive and, overall, an absolutely unbearable guy. He lacks any kind of social skills - understanding and empathy for oher characters are definetly not his forte. Problem is, he is also not some kind of sociopatic genius, who does not need other people to realise his grand scheme of things. Instead, he desperately NEEDS help from othr characters to survive, but, throughout the game, he literally makes the lives of everyone around him worse, whether those individuals are helping him, furthering their own agendas, or even showing him attraction/love. All in all, if you did not play this game and would like to imagine Nikolai - think about the worst person you have seen in your life and multiply them by cancer. 

The thing is, that it would not have been such a problem for myself, if Nikolai had an ark. Something like "A bad guy realising the errors of his ways" or "A spoiled child meets other people with hard lifes, who chang his view on the world" would have been a classic approach. But no, no, no - the screenwriter has decided it would be a magnificent idea to create the worst main character and have it that way from the first to the last letter of this story. And yes, this happens regardless of player choices. Most of them reprasent a dilemma of being either jerk or an asshole - a typical "Witcher" kind of a choice. And even if the player is presented withc some choice, which actually makes some sense, Nikolai still finds the way to be THE unbearable guy in the room. And yes, even at the very end of the story, where there are no more secrets and all cards are on deck, the protagonist still refuses to change and stays the same right 'till the rolling credits.

I really wanted to like this game, being the backer from 2017 and patiently waiting. And I still pretty much like everything that isn't Nikolai in this story. It is simple, even naive, but it could have worked. Could have...
I sincerely wish that the money I paid mostly went to the people writing the OST, drawing the beatiful arts and animations and to the programmers who actually did a good job of making a Ren'Py game not shit. But I know very well the it is not true and that the money mostly went to the "leader" of the studio and also the main screenwriter, who wrote the Nikolai in the first place. All in all, it is just a shame.

[b]Love, Money, Rock'n'Roll[/b] is a visual novel cum RPG by those folks who brought us [b]Everlasting Summer[/b] as a free VN a few years back. The Soviet Games team has been working hard since then on developing this game for us to enjoy.

123553981.review:
Hey, wow, this game is great!

I put it on my wishlist ages ago, and kinda forgot about it. :(  Noticed it had a price recently, so here we are.

There's an interesting story, multifaceted characters, and check out the art and music, there's a lot of really good stuff in here.  It plays perfectly on a Steam Deck, which probably explains why Steam thinks I only played for 3.0 hours.  It took about 45 hours on my Deck to see everything, if that matters to anyone.

Hmm, not going to spoil anything, just play it and see what happens.  Then play it again.  Don't go looking for a walkthrough, or at least try to resist the temptation as long as you can.  If you're in a hurry, like most visual novels you can fast-forward stuff you've seen before.

Several plot threads might appear to be cut short or forgotten in your first playthrough, so if you only play a game once you'll be missing most of the fun here.  You'll have to make different choices through several different routes to see how all the disparate story lines are connected, and what's really happening.

Some random stuff -

Don't quit when it feels like you're heading for one of the "bad ends" - things may turn out bad for some of the characters, but keep going to the finish, they are good reading for the player. :)  Plus you can turn on hints if you're struggling to connect with the right girl, whoever that may be.

Also, [spoiler]there's no "harem route" where all the cute girls fall in love with the protagonist simultaneously, and everyone lives happily ever after.  No, that's not gonna happen.[/spoiler] :)

Apparently there's a [i]patch[/i].  I couldn't figure out how to make it do anything on my Deck, so I gave up.  Not sure what I missed, but there were several fade-to-black moments in various playthroughs.  I'll use my imagination and say there were boobies everywhere, plus a secret harem route.  Probably had Himitsu's angry friend in there, too.

I sat through the full list of thank-yous for the "Patience is a virtue" cheevo and felt trolled pretty hard.  There's a lot of names.  Like, my Deck kept going to sleep.  I couldn't decide if I should keep going, or quit and leave it running overnight on my pc instead.  I must have seen a couple hours of names scroll past before it finished. :) Now, I don't know anything about the development of this game, so maybe without all of those contributors the game doesn't exist, so thank you, everyone!  But perhaps, if it's not too much trouble, could the list of wonderful people who contributed for the next game scroll a [i]tiny[/i] bit faster, please? :) Thank you!

Ok, this game is slightly more expensive than https://store.steampowered.com/app/331470/Everlasting_Summer/ but it's definitely worth your money.  If you're broke, you could add it to your wishlist and hope for a discount some day, but who knows when that's going to happen?  If you can afford it, go for it!

So I've spent a lot more time in this game than I would have expected to spend in visual novel, but it's oddly addictive for how simple it is.

First off, let's address the elephant in the room: If you're looking to have a wank, this isn't the game for you. The game is purely about romance and as of yet there are no sex scenes/nudity in the game, but I'm sure eventually one of you perverts reading this will work to solve that problem.

The main character is an outcast with no social skills [spoiler](relatable)[/spoiler] and no desire to pursue academic success (or any success for that matter). A lot of people in the reviews seem to have criticized him for his unstable and erratic personality, I didn't mind this aspect that much, but maybe it's because I am also a scumbag who despises society just like him. The personality of the girls are of the complexity of a 7 sided rubik's cube, just when you think you have them figured out, you find out there's more.

The story of the game despite being enjoyable is slow paced and really long. The choice system in the game is structured in a way that makes it really hard to get a good ending and most endings will be bad, this is because the game is very unforgiving of inconsistent choices, making it challenging and also realistic, (cause it do be hard to get that p*ssy when chasing after 2 chicks) some people may find this aspect lame, but I think it's way better than having a cheap story with easy choices just for some sexy scenes at the end.

The soundtrack is awesome and the visuals might not be the best, but they're good enough to create immersion.

The biggest let-down for me was encountering a major bug that has prevented me from getting all the endings. Which is quite annoying, but no-one else seems to have this issue and I'm sure it will be patched at some point.

121852568.review:
Everlasting Summer *used* to be my favorite story of all time. Encapsulating every kind of story, I’m serious. I mean books, movies, TV shows, video games. Out of all of those, Love, Money, Rock’n’Roll is my favorite. Now I don’t want to write this review for only those who have played Everlasting Summer already (if you haven’t, do it. It’s free. It’s cringe. But it’s amazing.) But I will often make comparisons. And I want to kick it off with this one: In Everlasting Summer, all of the endings contributed to a greater theme, and were all tied together (in a way). Of course LMR has its themes, but I would not venture to say all the endings can be satisfyingly wrapped around each other with one message. I was missing that aspect, but I have to respect that it’s a part of what made Everlasting Summer uniquely impactful. That is not to say that LMR DOESN’T take advantage of the fact that it’s a Visual Novel with many endings. It very much does, in that, each ending provides different bits of information that contribute to the events unfolding outside of Nikolai’s perception. That’s something to love about Soviet Games. You HAVE to piece together the bigger picture.

Story: As I outlined above- one of the appealing aspects of this game is the fact that you will have to read between the lines, analyze motives, and experience all the different endings to understand the big picture narrative as well as possible. Hell, you might be disappointed to know that there are not *that many* definitive answers throughout the game. (sounds familiar?) But that’s a huge appeal. You’re forced to come up with your own theories and develop them as you play the game. Aside from talking up my favorite gimmick, the story is phenomenal. When talking about the story though, I want to point out that there are different stories occurring in one playthrough. There is the behind-the-scenes narrative that relates to the forces putting Nikolai in danger, and the oh-so-infamous introspection from a Soviet Games main character and his relationship with himself, as well as the constantly evolving relationships with the girls around Nikolai. All of them are amazing, and I want to draw another Everlasting Summer comparison here: Nikolai’s relationship with himself and his own thoughts are maybe not as compelling as Semyon’s, but Nikolai’s relationship with those around him are far better fleshed out and compelling. At the end of the day, this IS a dating simulator, but it’s the best damn dating sim I’ve ever read and in this regard, better than Everlasting Summer.

Characters: Phenomenal. I don’t want to dive into how I think all the main characters are exceedingly well written (down to their backstory) or how much depth they all have (a lot) and how well their emotions are portrayed cleverly by their thoughts, words AND actions (they are). Despite some of the characters seeming annoying and nonsensical at first, every single word and action is justified by some point or in some ending. That is the most important thing. But what I really appreciate about LMR as well is that there is clever use made of side characters, and the impact they have on Nikolai. Across the character board, LMR sweeps Everlasting Summer. ESPECIALLY the side characters, who actually have depth and importance in the greater narrative. The ones that show up once or twice, and impact Nikolai’s perspective in a real, impactful way. Except for one. Who is inexplicably poorly written in, and obviously a character introduced by an IndieGoGo backer who bought the “make your own character” tier.

Music: No instant bangers like Blow With the Fires, and to be honest, it took me some time for the soundtrack to grow on me. I chalk that up to associating the music with different scenes in the game that have a great emotional weight in them. That happened with Everlasting Summer too. Sweet Pancakes and Strawberry Jam will start out as an okayish VN background song, and by the end of the game, it’s gonna have some serious weight. It’s just a shame there are no instant bangers like Blow With the Fires or Everlasting Summer that are really good to begin with, and made phenomenal by their clever placement in the game and their contribution to the experience. Again, not bangers, but I really like Satellite Dishes, Hollow, Echo Avenue and Red Miata.

Art: Wow, there was some kind of art direction occurring! Unlike in Everlasting Summer! Beautiful backgrounds by ArseniXC that look familiar, some CGs that have obviously had more work put into them than others, and animated sprites (fun!). The overall art direction and cohesiveness of visual effects is pretty good, but not perfect. Just look at those pictures up there though - they speak for themselves.

Decisions: I acknowledge that the previous sections have been a jerk-fest. So I’ll dedicate this one to honest criticisms I’ve seen. Firstly, the best criticism I’ve heard from others is the feeling that the choices presented do not impact the story in a drastic enough way. There is a specific way that the decisions in this game work, and it’s similar to Everlasting Summer if you played that. The way I would justify the feeling that the game is “on rails” is that Nikolai is supposed to be a full fledged character that will take most actions on his own, and this is a visual novel so obviously there are choices that you have to make for him. Perhaps where some of the decisions are should have been re-evaluated to alleviate that feeling, but I personally do not take issue with it. Secondly, the pacing of the decisions. That is another fair criticism, in that, at the beginning of the game, there are many many decisions, and then you get put on another path where there are less choices, and then another where there are even fewer. I understand the desire for the pacing to be different, but when you come to understand exactly how the decision making and branching story works in this game, I think it can be justified. I personally appreciate the unique way Soviet Games handles decisions, you may not though.

Conclusion: This VN will suck you in with its immersive world building, fleshed out characters (including an MC with real depth, as aggravating as he can be), solid music, beautiful art and that guilty pleasure DreamTale dialogue. Seriously, what makes Soviet Games my absolute favorite is the fact that the main characters are developed so well by their introspection lines. You will never get such an intimate understanding of a main character’s personality in any media as you will in a Soviet Games game.

Thank you, Soviet Games. Since I read Everlasting Summer in 2017, I had been patiently awaiting the release of Love, Money, Rock’n’Roll. I proudly donated on IndieGoGo. And read every IndieGoGo backer newsletter in my email since I was 16! I could only afford a game key back in 2017, but if I could now, I would go for that sweet signed copy and physical art book! Love, Money, Rock’n’Roll truly takes advantage of so many of the things that made Everlasting Summer unique and awesome, and added much more polish! Since my two favorite works of fiction now are Russian, I have decided to learn it, and I have a clear end goal for all that studying! I have almost finished learning the Russian Alphabet!
