121371419.review:
I really want to recommend this - I really do. But! There's always a but... Also, this contains spoilers, so yeah.

I will skip the part where while I (and many others) have been waiting for years and raised nearly $100k, the dev was [url=https://vk.com/wall209302115_44335]shitposting[/url] and playing FIFA. I will also skip the part where the English version is riddled with typos and mistakes that are not fixed, unlike the Russian script. AND the part where I was promised exclusive wallpapers as a backer, but wasn't sent any.

Let's start with CGs, shall we? There is a noticeable difference as the game progresses, especially if you compare the demo and the late-game full title. Two examples that are still fresh in my mind are a flashback with Himitsu and the crown thingy, where her face is just pitiful to watch, and the scene in the warehouse in Kagome's route. In general, it's like some of the CGs were made by different people, and I wouldn't be surprised if that's the case.

Story - I enjoyed the Ellie - Kagome direction to an extent (will talk about why "to an extent" later), even though there're loads of plot holes and you're still left with little to no information about what happened even if you complete all the endings (which I did).

You probably never asked why "to an extent", but since you're reading this, I'll tell you anyway. If you follow a fandom or the development process and have seen the comments, you might rightly guess that it's the MC's indecisiveness. Some said that "it's just how he is", but there isn't much of a backstory, and when there is, it's not fully disclosed, again, even on all endings completed, and as such the motivation for Niko to be like this (a spineless retard) is unknown. Maybe if I knew why, I would've seen him differently, but the scriptwriter didn't bother and from this standpoint the MC only meets pity and resentment from me.

Himitsu - Catherine route is cursed with this, most likely. This inability to make decisions might fit well into El - Ka one, and in most bad endings Niko fully deserved the ending itself, but Hi - Ca... Bloody hell. In Himitsu's route he pursues Kate, in Kate's - it's Himitsu, and so even after several choices that will, from Nikolai's words, make him steer clear of the other girl, you can be sure she will appear and get in the way, and MC will be too much of a doormat to do anything about it. I will ALSO skip that Catherine appears in all 4 routes to a relatively large extent, and if you're not aware, "thinking about Catherine" has become a meme in itself. Phew, the hard part is over.

I want to summarise the positives, as I still think this is a somewhat decent/average title. The music is absolutely fantastic, and buying the soundtrack in worth every penny, especially for those who enjoy rock and retrowave. The backgrounds are surprisingly consistent in being nice, as well as the characters and animations. Throwing away some of the CGs and the MC's behaviour, it's really good. But unless you're a fan of action with turbulent romance mixed in and loads of drama, I cannot recommend it. And if you are, there are better titles to convey that, like Ever17.

Thanks for reading! I have somewhat enjoyed this title, even if almost not at all, and I hope you will too if you decide to give it a try.

121359316.review:
Наверное ну нафиг эти обзоры,долгие монологи ,рассуждения. Если брать оценку по шкале Stopgame ,то однозначно «Похвально».
Похвально - что игра увидела свет,что она цепляет музыкой,галереей,да и 2D Live тибики на экране в ВН это что-то новое.
Игра увлекает и это более чем весомая причина поиграть.На личном опыте испытать весь спектр эмоций представленных игрой.Чего уж тут,авторы умеют как удивить,так и разочаровать.Как поднять планку качества,так и пробить дно с которого никто не постучит.
И все же главное достоинство - она самобытна.Как игра,как история,как эксперимент - в конце концов как аттракцион эмоций,хоть и не всегда положительных. По меркам ВН, или даже просто игры в целом - это уже чего-то стоит.
Может кому-то этого хватит? 

>Если вы - ждали игру с анонса,впитывали каждое обещание как губка,в надежде что она будет именно такой как обещали,как она планировалась когда-то.
Или возможно вы глубинный эстет цепляющийся исключительно за историю,повествования или персонажей - то можете готовится к худшему,к потраченному вникуда времени например.
>Любителям более лайтового наверняка придется по душе.Возможно зацепит какая-нибудь из местных вайфу,или понравится поверхностное повествование.А может и местные юморезки или попытка в "ромком".

Касаемо технической части - почти все на ура. Особенно классными вышли спрайты фонов и музыка.Композиции...Я бы сказал они божественны ИМХО.Да и наверное мог бы часами обсуждать как их,так и эмоции которые они вызывают.Та же "Hollow" - которая сама по себе внушает ощущение триллера. Или "In this very moment" / "The door to nowhere" - от которых непроизвольно наворачиваются слезы.
Отдельный плюс за "Everlasting reference",да и думаю хватит с меня этого пункта.
Приятные иллюстрации.Но вот 2d live тибики - вышли относительно сносными.Симпатичные и вполне живые на вид,но вот анимации средние,а местами совсем хромают.

Говоря со спойлерами.В игре столько всего понамешанно, что иногда не понимаешь к чему.К чему излишний цирк или вода к некоторых рутах.К чему было избавляться от главного рута,у нас на руках только концовки с девчушками.К чему постоянная излишняя драма высосанная из пальца.
Разочаровывающая развилка главной ветки.И да господи как же я устал от перетягивания одеяла внимания девушек,как в дешевых ромкомах. Только если ты знаешь,что там это комедийная одноразовая вставка,что это мимолетный момент.То здесь это каждый раз ТРАГЕДИЯ - которая как кажется закончится самовыпилом игрока.

Если начать разговор о персонажах,то все относительно.Можно конечно сказать вкратце,что раскрыты они сносно.Однако слишком много недомолвок.
Начиная уже с главного героя - с представлением которого нас обломали уже со старту.Экспозиция отсутствует напрочь.
Какая-то Кетрин,Химицу, да кто этот НИК и почему он ведет себя как истеричка? Догадывайтесь сами,или нет - авторов сценария не волнует.Нам постоянно тычат переживаниями ГГ,об неудачных отношениях ("предательстве" Кэтрин),трагичных событиях и прочем - но так ли они весомы?Можно выкинуть из головы,нам как читателю об этом особо не расскажут.Переживать за героя или гореть с его поступков - выбор за вами зависящий от вашей призмы восприятия.


Хорошей получилась ветка Эли - нет замаха как и особых претензий.Да и персонаж без лишней воды и драмы воспринимается по другому.
Кетрин - два сапога пара.Если по субъективной оценке где-то между Эли и остальными.Персонажу в целом можно сопереживать,вполне приземленно (по мерками игры) прописан.После столького негатива к ней особо не поругаешь.Другое дело сам рут.
Кагомэ и Химицу - персонажи вышли сносными,какие-никакие расплывчатые мотивы и раскрытие.Их руты пытаются играть на эмоциях,но сценарий недоигрывает.
Все руты кроме Эли - сплошной сюр,постепенно уводящий от основной ветки,да так что можно и забыть ее существование.
Как их повествование,так и концовки расплывчатый уход в закат...

Сценарий основной ветки неплохой ИМХО,казалось планка качества постепенно шагает в верх.Но увы к развилкам все катится на дно.Руты кажутся совершенно обособленными,не связанными с основной веткой,как будто фанфики сшитые тонкими нитками.А концовки кажутся написанными по одному шаблону.И хорошие,и плохие - с каждым разом все больше сходств.
Даже концовки с мгновенной кармой кажутся более изящными.
Ах да,еще же была детективная ветка...Тут можно поставить только неуд.Корабль этого сценарного решения тонет вместе с переживаниями героя.Должного раскрытия они не получают,да и выглядят скорее как троллинг игроков.

Во-вторых, мне нравится что героини имеют хоть какое-то "мясо" в сценарном плане. Единственное с чем я согласен в плане претензий, так это то что выборы, зачастую, кажутся уж слишком неочевидными. Но для меня это скорее плюс, чем минус. Моя оценка: 88/100. Рекомендую. Ценник оправдан - игра длинная, под 40 часов.

121289360.review:
As someone who was waiting since 2018 for this game to release, I have to say it was worth the wait. While a couple of scenes here and there looked unfinished and there were a few translation errors, mostly everything was polished. Particularly I'm impressed with the amount of effort they put into creating the models. Not only do side characters get their own character models and expressions, but even some one-off characters too so you're not just talking to an empty background most of the time. The music was good, good enough that when it repeats, it's not annoying to listen to. 

Nikolai is definitely a different protagonist than those in most VNs I'm familiar with, having a distinct, stubborn personality. He comes across like a jerk at times, which can take some getting used to. Most of the characters are fleshed out, and I found myself enjoying each girl's plotline for different reasons. My first playthrough took me about ~17 hours at a comfortable pace, so this is not a short VN by any means (though subsequent playthroughs will obviously be shorter). 

If you're looking for a long "dating sim" VN with a good story and serious, sometimes balls-to-the-wall tone, then I'd definitely recommend this. A wonderful addition to the genre from Soviet Games!!

121047212.review: The story is on point for 2/4 of the routes. If you want to see what this studio can do producing short of Clannad level writing/story telling, go through the Ellie and Kagome routes first. There is a clear, but understandable set of problems/events that the main character goes through for these two. It's honestly the shining light of this visual novel. The real problems come when you hit the Himitsu and Catherine routes. The premise of these two routes are still really good. Where they fall short is through the decision making of the main character. I my opinion there isnt enough preface to Catherine being this huge divide in Nikolai's life. You get some context in their version of a prologue, but nothing more than a vague first love interest. It's very frustrating attempting to go down Himitsu's path but still having the main character hold such strong desire to love Catherine, without very much justification for his thoughts or actions. Thats where I believe that this game falls on its face. Theres just too much priority placed on Catherine, which gives off a forced and nonsensical nature to Nikolai's thoughts and actions. Honestly if they'd clean up Catherine's and Himitsu's routes by taking a different perspective and non pragmatic approach for Nikolai, I think this game would easily be recommended by 95% or more of the community here. Overall I still think this game is a good buy. The graphics are top notch for a VN along with the interesting art style and great music. People complaining about spelling and grammatical errors are just nit picking, as there are very few. Overall this game gets like a 8/10.

120997896.review: Как всегда разработчики порадовали увлекательностью сюжета, когда зачастую нельзя предсказать, что произойдёт дальше. Причём история достаточно подробно показана, и не набросками, что роднит проект с произведением "Сулажин" у Акунина , когда выборов относительно мало, а рассказа много. 120951509.review:
Playtime: 6.5 hours on another account, but I can't hold myself back from writing a review. Long story short, this game is complete, utter garbage.   Why? Reasons stated down:

1. The main character is a complete cuck, by both Russian and anime standards, leading a very prestigious life (pretty much like a king or a son of a Russian oligarch), attending a prestigious school, having almost 0 obligations other than getting his pathetic body to wake up in the morning and move it to school without the need to even learn, managing to somehow even look European despite being a Russian, having a very beautiful, and an extremely patient girl love him without being oblivious to it. All he does with the aforementioned things is just waste them and ruck up in the worst ways possible, his interactions with people, and the world can be summed up to two things: Lying and complaining. He lies to everyone, at any time, even when it's completely unnecessary, which is most of the time, even to himself, believing his own lies to be true like a real Russian. And after that he just whines about how everybody else is either cruel or too boring to grace his ungrateful self with his attention (Himitsu, Kyosuke), and then bashes Japan (in his own mind, of course, can't afford anyone to talk back and point out that he's just projecting Russian problems on them) and puts down people that care about him to feel better about himself, while willingly, without the need to do that, humiliating himself before everyone that doesn't care about him or wants nothing to do with him. Dostoyevsky tier. He does so much for them, and they don't care because they were completely ignorant of these delusions of grandeur and obligations in the first place.  Lives like a king, and does this with his life, the worst anime characters in the worst visual novels and JRPGs I've seen are better characters than him because they usually start up bad but manage to become tolerable-to-normal people in the end, also usually helping people out on their way and managing to competently do what is asked of them.

2. This partially relates to the first point because it has to do with the story, but is mostly gameplay-related. The main character is unable to ever make up his mind and his choices barely matter, if you choose to not do something, he still does it afterwards because he feels bad about people that don't care about him because he wants them to care, but gets only contempt in the end. Gameplay-wise, this is boring and frustrating, story-wise, it's just unrealistically dumb. An average Uzbek in a Russian school could pull off something as hard (in the protagonist's perspective, since everything easy is a struggle for him) as not caring about a girl that does not like him, but this Russian incubator emo has to obsessively chase girls that he chooses not to chase because he has an evident attention deficit.

3. Redundant, superfluous, infuriatingly dumb thoughts of the main character. Excessively lyrical, never to the point and having close to no substance virtually all the time. It's realistic for a Russian, but it's very taxing on an educated Western person to read something like this. 

4. The way the characters are made displays how little frame of reference the developers have for the rest of the world, or even Russia.. The protagonist and a half-Russian, half-Japanese girl (Himitsu) look European, a supposed American character (Elile) has a Japanese surname despite looking European, Kyousuke looks like exactly like a fat Kazakh I've seen on a vacation in Kazakhstan, along with Michael. The other Japanese characters look like Turks on a various range from Kazakh to Tatar to Bashkir to Russian,  All of which is completely unfitting, not a single character looks realistic for their supposed heritage. All characters act, think, talk Russian and not Japanese or Western, which would be fine if it were a game set in Russia and not Japan, but it is what it is, and it's bad.

5. Blatant racism and xenophobia are clearly seen in the game as the protagonist discriminates against people of American and Japanese heritage, or seeks to demean them to feel good about himself, or justify himself. Everyone around him is bad but he's the only one that is good. It serves no narrative purpose, he can easily remain a whining schmuck without discriminating against people on account of ethnocultural background and generalizing them.

6. Subtle war propaganda for the Russian state, the inevitable main storyline makes you cross paths with a girl singing in a band called "Z FeelZ", showcasing a clearly outlined symbol of the Russian aggression against the Ukraine, and encourages you to want to chase her and appreciate her music, cheap song sung in an unfitting and strongly noticeable Russian accent for a character that's not even supposed to be Russian. The game script, as well as the main character tries to talk you into accepting that Russians are innocent and everybody else is just out for them, which so coincidentally happens to be the same narrative the warmongering Russian state propaganda pushes on its people.

7. No voiced lines. There is a lot, and I mean a LOT of effort put into irrelevant background details like animating random things, or making fitting ambient sounds, but close to nothing has been done for things that really matter, like the story, or making voiced lines or serviceable main characters, unless of course it has all gone in accordance with what was desired - a boring, stupid, annoying, racist, xenophobic depiction of how Russians perceive the outside world, filled with Russian insecurities. 
This game should not be on Steam.

120948833.review:
This game speaks to me on a very personal level.  While I was not in Tokyo in 1987, I was definitely a teenager in a rich kid's school in the United States - Los Angeles.  Both my parents worked for a defense contractor; one of the big, spooky ones where they couldn't talk about their work and when we traveled, we had to check in with the Consulate as both had high security clearances.  (Not gonna say which one, and they weren't murdered)  The parallels and the relation to my own life is eerie.  This game gets so much right, it is perfect and immersive to me...except when they get a few little things wrong.  Those little things in an otherwise perfect game, are a little jarring to someone who actually was around AND a teenager in 1987.  Some of the things the characters say aren't things we said back then.  Certain things didn't exist.  Other things did.  Not going to nitpick this great game because by and large I enjoyed it - to the point where I could "what if" My own Katty-Chan, my own Himitsu, my own Kagome, and my own Ellie-San.

My own Ellie-San was never interested in me.  Never spoke more than a few sentences at a time.  She married another rock star.

My own Himitsu, I married - and she tired of me.

My own Katty-chan married Michael, which was devastating to me.

And I never really had a Kagome that I recognized. Edit:  Yes, yes I did.  I remember now with sadness and more than a little shame:  I never really gave her a chance (she was contrary like Kagome, which, to be fair, was kinda irritating to me at the time).  I probably should have paid a lot more attention to her and less to the other girls; maybe my life would have turned out differently.

I told you the parallels were striking.  This game gave me an almost-perfect portal to the past.

Almost.

Sometimes it is painful to remember how stupid you were, the clues you never saw at the time, only in hindsight, and sometimes it seems like just yesterday you WERE that person.  But that was thirty-five years ago.

Sure it hurts, but the brilliance of this game is that it TOOK ME THERE.  And I cannot express enough how wonderful that is, with all the emotional ups and downs that go with it.

Even the little touches like the VHS-like bars on the transitions and the fast-forward - awesome stuff that most people these days wouldn't realize are Easter eggs for the people who lived during that time and actually did those things.

So thank you, Soviet Games, for another hit that managed to make me cry.  The memories are still there.

I've gone through all the playthroughs, but I think I'm going to go through them again.

Because memories.

I miss those days.

And it's a reminder that I don't have my whole life ahead of me anymore.  My life, my "future" has become history, mostly forgotten, occasionally remembered, and sometimes accurately portrayed.

I can forgive the typos, some of the weird syntax issues I know come from translating Russian to English, but some of the tech moments are...jarring.  

But again, while they are on my mind, I'm not going to complain about the few flaws in perfection otherwise.

Gameplay is similar to Everlasting Summer.  Consequences of choices are sometimes obvious, sometimes not.  Text is verbose, but the right combination of analysis and emotion that is the hallmark of those weird late-teen school years.  Far too many "Yup, I felt like that" moments to even count.

Dunno if you will like it, but I did.  Very much.  It's my own private portal into history.  MY history.

Edited 2/9/2023

120869277.review:
Quite possibly the worst VN I have ever had the displeasure of playing. Although the visuals and music are quite good, pretty much everything else is horrendous. Virtually every character in LMR is insufferable in every sense of the word, from Nikolai himself (ESPECIALLY him), to the 4 "heroines", to nearly every major side character. The story-lines are poorly paced, with several elements in each of the routes that are either introduced and never resolved, or are quickly dismissed, despite the game continuously trying to insist it's something that is important. This is also not helped in the length of the game, which, although impressive, quickly develops into a tedious slog. (Especially when a large portion of the game is Nikolai pointlessly spouting pseudo-intellectual drivel that contributes nothing or has no real relevance to what's actually happening.)

As for the driving forces of the routes themselves (the girls), they are possibly the worst heroines in any VN ever conceived. They all run the gambit from delusional to having instances of being downright mentally unstable, and have very few (if any) instances that lead you to develop any sort of connection/care about what happens to them. Even in the good endings, due to the development of the characters, the game ends up failing to evoke any sort of emotion, other than relief that it's over.

And last, but most CERTAINLY not least, we have Nikolai. To compliment the terrible heroines, we have a protagonist that somehow, against all odds, manages to be exponentially worse. Nikolai has pretty much nothing redeeming about him. He's constantly rude to everyone, is spineless despite how many times he is the cause of the problem, lashes out at everyone constantly, takes advantage of people around him, and is in general a downright terrible person. It's painful to experience a VN of this length with a main character that is so unlikable you wind up actively wishing he would fail.

The Bartender and Tokyo Rider are cool, though, so that's something.

120709008.review:
there's a lot of pros and cons here, but most importantly, I think it boils down to this: if you were a big fan of Everlasting Summer, with all its weirdness and unique, janky charm, then LMR is well worth your time. If you've never played a visual novel, or are just a casual fan debating on whether or not you should try this out, I'd say wait just a little while. 

The english translation (as well as many of the other language options, i suspect), needs a pretty decent touch-up. It's perfectly readable, but the unreasonable amount of typos and grammar mistakes can be a bit distracting. That's not a big deal with a free game like ES, but this vn is a very different beast from that one, and I think the devs need to direct some effort toward refining that aspect. They've also been pussyfooting around the matter of a patch to add 18+ content to the game. To me, and to plenty of other people, the presence or absence of that doesn't really matter all that much, the issue I think a lot of people have is the lack of consistent and clear communication about what Soviet Games intentions are when it comes to a patch. The 18+ patch for ES added a fair bit of content that was otherwise totally unavailable, and whether they are or aren't planning to do something similar with LMR, their lack of commitment isn't all that inspiring. It's a crazy time all around the world, though, so hey, no big deal.

Those are the main non-story related downsides I can think of. Without going into spoilers, I'll just say that, as others have pointed out, the pacing and narration from the MC can feel a bit off at times. It's not an overwhelming, fundamental issue with the routes themselves, it's just something that creeps up on you now and then, usually in what feels like what should be the climax of a particular storyline. The synopses look great on paper, but it seems like they struggled at some points when it came to committing lines to the script. At some points, it feels like way too much. At others, not quite enough. It can sometimes feel like you know you're at the big moment of the story, where all the pieces of the puzzle are supposed to be falling together, but for some reason they just drag it out seemingly endlessly. I wouldn't go so far as to say there's a problem with filler here, but like I said, the pacing is way off at times. 

The sheer variety available in the routes is what makes up for it. I'm honestly really impressed with that aspect of the VN, and commend Soviet Games for it. I've not finished all of them yet, but the ones I have finished left me feeling quite satisfied-- like I'd experienced something that was different enough from what I'd seen already to make it worth the time. Other than that, the music is great, character designs are a step up from ES, and the artwork is as beautiful and intricately detailed as ever. 

This comes with strong recommendations for fans of Everlasting Summer, with the caveat that you should expect a story and experience that is a bit of a departure from it. I'm glad to have spent the time with it that I have so far, and I think this is one of those VNs that I'll come to appreciate and admire more and more as time goes on.

8/10. easily a 9 with some updates for the translation.

120563824.review:
[h1] Пятилетку за семь [/h1]

Сложно объективно оценивать игру, которую предзаказал 7 лет назад. Тогда даже доллар был дешевле чем сейчас. И я не буду даже пытаться это сделать, 

Я не спец по визуальным новеллам и пройденные тайтлы можно пересчитать по пальцам двух рук. "Бесконечное Лето", от этой же студии, в своё время было воспринято мною крайне тепло и как ни старайся, но сравнение этих игр всё равно напрашивается. Но и этого делать я не буду. Я постараюсь написать лишь то, что мне как обычному игроку бросалось в глаза.

Если игра способна полностью тебя захватить. Забрать всё твоё внимание. Заставить денёк-другой походить в себе. Задуматься. "Земля вызывает... Приём". Эта игра стоит свеч. Даже если она не идеальна. Даже если она соответствует ожиданиям. Почти 30 часов я не мог отвлекаться на другие занятия в свободное время, а значит что-то тянет вернуться туда. Узнать, что будет дальше. Посмотреть - что было бы если... Эта игра стоила того.

[b] Плюсы: [/b]
-Разработчики. Мне приятно что мои соотечественники могут сделать подобную игру. Не шедевр, но уже уровень
-Анимированные персонажи и фоны. Маленькие детальки, которые очень радуют глаз. Поезд, которые проезжает по основной улице - вообще шедевр
-Стиль речи. Простой и понятный. Читается легко. К некоторым словам даны пояснения, что не может не радовать.

[b] Минусы: [/b]
-Концовки
Хорошая концовка, от которой я ожидал больше всего - отказалась самой непонятной и открытой. Такое ощущение, что её просто забыли дописать. События возникали из ниоткуда а от происходящего оставалось только больше вопросов. При чём попасть на неё получилось только после приличного количества перепрохождений, т.к. далеко не самый очевидный выбор в диалоге, который казалось бы ни на что не влияет, в итоге не давал дойти до хорошего финала. В итоге самой запавшей в душу осталась одна из плохих концовок
Нет ни одной концовки не связанной с кем-то из героинь
-Руты
Не понравилась система попарных рутов. Один выбор (при чём далеко не очевидный) сразу отсекает 2 других рута. Понять это можно, только методом нескольких перепрохождений. Мне кажется что бальная (которая, к слову в игре есть, но используется дальше), была бы тут уместнее.
-Сюжет
Создатели преподносят 4 разных сюжета - в зависимости от выбора рута. Свзывают эти сюжет только единый сеттинг и общие детали. ГГ не особо участвует в развитии сюжет и от того кажется очень странным что на день N в первом руте произошли одни события, а на этот же день в другом руте события происходят диаметрально противополжные, при чём никаких объяснений этому не даётся. В итоге - на все вопросы которые возникают в ходе прохождения одного рута и остаются открытыми - ответа нигде нет. Мне бы хотелось видеть единый сюжет, который в зависимости от выбранного рута раскрывался с разных углов. Показывал то - что не было видно до этого. И при полном прохождении имелась бы полноценная картин. Законченный сюжет. Но имеем, что имеем...
-Персонажи
У меня создалось ощущение, что из 4х рутов 2 являются основными, а 2 побочными, просто что бы наполнить игру. При чём из этих двух основных, один мне казался как-то более "основным" что ли... В итоге у меня создалось впечатление, что есть один основной рут, а остальные 3 призваны заполнить игру. От того было только тяжелее, что наречённый мною "Основной" рут отказался самым открытым, а как по мне - так и вовсе недописанным. Но - это уже совсем субъективно

[/b] Заключение: [/b]
Всё описанное выше является сугубо субъективным мнением и даже близко не претендует на хоть какую - то объективность.
Пусть я покупал это произведение 7 лет назад, когда стоимость товара, а равно и доллара была другая - я бы не пожалел денег и купил её сейчас.
Когда появлялась возможность сесть за компьютер - я абсолютно забывал кто я, где я и почему я. Отвлекаясь от естественного течения бытия я полностью погружался в игру и благодарен авторам за эту возможность.
Игра стоит своих денег

120558817.review:
Love, Money, Rock`n`Roll has been released in the worst time possible in terms of amount of people, who would like to familiarize itself with the game. And the studio`s name does make it more difficult. Russian culture is associated with fascism, occupation and destruction as were Italian and Japanese ones one day. Should I make a point that a nation`s culture is a complex entity even if it seems that this given nation is an embodiment of irrational evil? I`ll try to advocate for this game since it deserves more recognition than it`ll get.

Firstly, yes, the game makes references to Russian and Japanese cultures from time to time. It would be odd, if there had been none, because the story revolves around Nickolas, russian teenager living in Tokyo in 1987. Have you heard of Dostoyevski? You can try a novel of his, you`re fond of grim Scandinavian criminal dramas. Secondly, no, this isn`t just anoher commie agitation crap. Authors occasionally drop snide comments on standard of living in USSR, its insidious agents and their methods.

The plot is pretty captivating in the first half of the game, and thrilling in the second (wherever your choices will lead you). I can recall two books that have left me with such a pleasant aftertaste after finale: Flowers for Algernon and Steins Gate. Have you dreamed of inhereting a house and a small fortune at the very dawn of your life, being attractive enough to enjoy implausible amount of attention from opposite sex? Well, there`s a fly in the ointment: you`re an orphan and an immigrant. Though, the latter is the least issue, the protagonist assimilated profoundly over many years. 120492440.review:
First (very all over the place) impressions after playing the demo a few times during development and one route down (Himitsu)

TLDR;; was worth the 10 dollar preorder price, would probably pay the full price but don’t expect the title to be a good indicator of what to expect story wise. so far I’ve encountered a story that is messy, toxic, dramatic, and a bit over the top at times. cold war adjacent mystery/romance with side plots and great visuals/music. probably faces problems with repetition in later runs.
_____ 

While I cannot really fully judge the story as a whole at my current level of completion, it’s fine enough. For the 10 dollars I paid for it during the preorder, I’m satisfied thus far, but I also tend to walk into things with low expectations just by default because I enjoy the pleasant surprise I get when something really appeases my brain. 

From the beginning, it feels as if you are thrusted directly into the Catherine and Himitsu saga. Makes a bit of sense since the game has the two girls being predetermined relationships before the game begin, but I would have liked to see more integration of Kagome and Ellie. Even while playing the demo, it’s hard to see how the choices could lead you away from Himitsu and Catherine in some capacity aside from a few essentially cameos of Kagome and Ellie at the beginning and a couple of appearances mid game unless you actively seek them(seeking out a route map feels fine enough in this situation imo if you are lost or desperate). 

Nikolai is well…just a guy. I’ve witnessed worse protagonists in VNs and print media. He’s rough, rude, quick to explode, can’t seem to let things go, and sometimes lacks empathy, and while his circumstances shouldn’t be an excuse for his actions or behavior, they do provide some context to them. He’s a witty guy at times, and winded and over philosophical others. Sometimes(a lot of times) he doesn’t make great choices, but hey, that’s life as he would probably say. Honestly, it’s kind of fun seeing him be a bit melodramatic with vices, but maybe that’s because I, too, have a flair for the theatrics, I suppose. I do like his design though. It’s not over the top, but he stands out to me. 

I don’t really have much to say about the girls thus far, but their designs are appealing to me and I love the integration of the Live2D sprites. It was a nice thing to see when I revisited the demo a while ago. They add a bit of…something to the game. Everyone has their own distinct look to them, and aren’t too maximalistic in design. Same could be said about the side characters, everyone has a pretty good design without being overly distracting or out of place.

The backgrounds are absolutely phenomenal, too. Especially since there’s chunks of dialogue with no sprite on screen. The UI itself is just nice too, I like it. 

Music, too, was wonderful. Absolutely enjoyed it in the background. 

The story is a bit, um, much sometimes while also lacking in some places. Reads fine, but sometimes it feels a bit like a rogue mystery romance AU gone wild. Or maybe even a soap opera at times. A lot of drama is happening at once and it happens very quickly. You wouldn’t know it really from the title, but, things go south for Nikolai Anokhin very quickly in ways that are outside of typical teenage interpersonal drama. I’m sure in the reread to get more routes, some of the information will feel repetitive to encounter, but alas, everything I’ve read so far is new information to add to the canon of the story. I absolutely love the addition of having important cultural information that might not be known to an international reader highlighted in blue with a definition when clicked, especially as someone who isn’t highly familiar with the culture of Japan or the USSR in late 80s or the mentioning of the occasional Russian classical literature.  

I personally find the cliches and drama to be a bit more entertaining in this VN than I did Everlasting Summer, and you can tell there was a great deal of effort put into the game. Whether you find that effort to be wholehearted and worth the price is up to you. I’d probably pay the 20 dollars for the game if I hadn’t preordered it a while ago. Perhaps it’s because I am a bit of a fool for silly teen drama with dramatic mystery overtones. It’s not Riverdale level of tacky, that’s for sure, but it definitely isn’t for someone looking for a happy, upbeat feel good with some angst VN. It’s about a teenage boy thrusted into a bunch of events he knew absolutely minimal about the details behind the scenes and having to pay the price for it, to the potential detriment of his personal relationships, some of them being romantic and messy at times. 

Further thoughts to maybe be added when I complete one of the Ellie/Kagome routes or more.

120486584.review:
I read through all the routes of this vn and it was a love-hate relationship. Even though it was super addictive with great atmosphere that sucked me in, there is a number of issues I'd like to tell you about.

1. Choices and pacing. Normally you would expect your choices to have meaningful impact. You would also expect such choices scattered throughout the story in a balanced manner and be a driving force behind the events that unfold. However, in LMR the majority of your choices are made early on and from that point you're just a bystander - the ending/epilogue oftentimes gets more screen time than everything that preceded it. Furthermore, the choices do not impact the story in a meaningful and obvious manner. You can choose to stay at home but you will still go outside because the story is pretty much on rails. Oftentimes some minor choices that should have no impact on the final outcome will play the decisive role in it. In the end, it all boils down to a subtle point calculation which happens behind the scenes, and unlocking certain endings would be a struggle without a walkthrough. Mechanics of "major" and "minor" choices would feel much welcome here.

2. Endings. Because the endings are mostly logically disconnected from your choices, getting them feels like reading different versions of the script rather than something cohesive. Ideally, different endings should help to piece the story together, and sometimes that even works. Most of the time, however, you will get 4 different explanations behind the same events based on your route, and you see the characters opening from very, very different sides. This makes it hard to understand what is canon for plot and character motivations - because they can end up super wholesome individuals or terrible monsters depending on whether you went to the bar or to the park. Bad endings are also the majority here, while a few good endings feel unrealistic, because of how much dragon killing and crazy plot twists are required to make them work.

3. Routes. There are really just two, "Himitsu - Catherine" and "Ellie - Kagome". No matter which of the girls you go for you will largely face the same events and the same recurring rivalry theme between them. Even though it makes sense from the point of storytelling, it leads to you having to read through quite a lot of stuff for girls you aren't really interested in. Story-wise, one route is too much of a spy thriller and another one is too much of Romeo and Juliet, and struggles between superpowers and corporations are neither particularly engaging nor what you're likely here for. 

4. Characters. They're terrible. Starting from the MC who is supposed to be a 18 y.o. school boy but thinks and acts as a 45 y.o washed-up drunk. He has no hobbies, ambitions, or will to live, and the only thing driving him is his fear of being alone; and has no other way of engaging with anyone other than being a pathological liar and egoistical jerk. The girls follow suit, with each being her own flavor of pure toxicity. Engaging with them leads to being dumped by everyone, beat to death, shot, buried alive, imprisoned, impoverished or having to run away and leave everything he held dear behind - in no particular order.

Please refund me my 50 hours.

120449218.review:
Reviewed after getting all 4 good endings

Pros:
- Really good art and music

-Decently interesting spy games/intrigue subplots, though the story in general is undercooked (see below)

-Tokyo Rider

Cons:
- MC is an unlikable, dishonest and spineless asshole and almost impossible to sympathize with - it's actually really hard to understand how he even manages to have 2 friends, let alone why 4 girls are attracted to him (actually maybe not, a couple of the girls are kind of... crazy).

-Especially the MC (but also the girls), everyone just seems to melodramatically freak out every 2 seconds. People don't really seem to behave like... people. (Hilariously, the MC is described as "throwing his hands up" so often, you sort imagine everyone who's ever been within a meter of him having gotten slapped in the face at least once by this)

- Storyline is poorly balanced between the various routes on a number of levels. 
[list]
[*]On Himitsu's route, the storyline and the MC still seem to be focused on Catherine (actually in general the MC still seems to be a bit too obsessed with Catherine even deep into all the other girls' routes, but especially on Himitsu's route, sometimes you feel like you're still basically on Catherine's story).

[*]As well, the intrigue, spy games and mysteries aren't really adequately explained/developed in any of the routes except Catherine's. And as those subplots form the background against which everything else happens, if you play any of the other routes first, you might be left kind of confused or with a lot of questions at the end. I played the Catherine route last, so I was left scratching my head on a lot of points for most of my playtime and that's actually why I played for so long since I tried to piece everything together from different routes. But even playing through all the non-Catherine routes, there will still be a lot of unanswered questions since those routes just have a lot of redundant information (at least for the spy games/intrigue subplots). On the other hand, once you play Catherine's route, you'll get a decent enough idea of most of the mystery/spy game subplots (as well as major spoilers for at least one other girl's route), meaning you also don't get the fun of piecing together the mysteries by playing through multiple routes.
[/list]

-Overly wordy and filled with rambling monologues. It's advertised that the game has over 500,000 words, but much of that is the MC's internal (or external) monologues, and it's often irrelevant to the plot and filled with annoying and not particularly deep pseudo-philosophizing ("why do people like different colors?"). The text could probably have been cut by 1/3 or 1/2 and that extra word count used to better develop the plot (see below).

-Plot is undercooked. Despite the massive word count, a lot of the important plot moments are underdeveloped, and seem to fly by in an instant, and are not very well explained or set up. This is the case even after finishing Catherine's route. There are also significant plot holes (for example, [spoiler]it's mentioned that Catherine had a miscarriage. If that's the case, how would the MC's doubtless extremely wise and expert "fatherly advice" or whether or not she moved back to the US have made a difference? And yet a huge deal is made out of this in the story, as if they would have.[/spoiler])

Random minor annoyances:
-Some of the Japanese names have significant errors - for example, with [spoiler]Akira Shinji[/spoiler], this character's surname and given name are actually both Japanese given names. Makes for a slightly annoying (or amusing) reading experience if you can speak Japanese or have experience with Japanese names. Himitsu would also make for a really weird/hilarious Japanese name, though it might be a Russian name or something, I don't know.

Overall: 4/10

120414970.review:
6 лет с публикации проекта на Kickstarter и 7 с момента анонса и наконец этот долгострой вышел. Но оправдал ли он ожидания? В первую очередь здесь МНОГО текста, порой ОЧЕНЬ МНОГО и лишь иногда СЛИШКОМ МНОГО. Но при этом повествование проседает очень редко и постоянно подбрасывает сюжетные твисты просто приятные моменты. Все 4 рута строятся вокруг общей канвы и каждый из них дает свой кусочек пазла и придется пройти все, чтобы собрать полную картину. Арты в игре очень красивые, но при этом заметно на каком этапе сменился художник и были сделаны жертвы в угоду более быстрого выхода игры. А вот за фоны отдельная благодарность ArseniXC. С музыкой же здесь абсолютно не подкопаться. Как и в Бесконечном лете ее можно рзделить на два условных жанра, да и самого рок-н-ролла здесь предостаточно. Самое главное что некоторые композиции хочется переслушивать снова и снова.

Что же о самих рутах, решение объединить девочек в пары было интересным и добавило глубины персонажам, так как есть возможность увидеть их с обоих сторон. К сожалению, Кетрин и Химицу досталось гораздо меньше выборов, особенно в финальной части игры, что делает процесс перепрохождения более длительным. Да и в целом руты Кагомэ и Эли показались более законченными и проработанными, хотя судя по отчетам писались они последними.

А вот касательно виновника торжества - он весьма неоднозначен. Да, с характером. Да. импульсивный. И местами очень неадекватный. Но это опять же чаще проявляется в рутах Химицу и Кетрин. Последнюю он будет упоминать до тех пор, пока вас тошнить не начнет и еще немного после этого. Неудивительно, что ее рут вышел пожалуй самым романтичным, хотя и при этом самым коротким, оборвав несколько веток на полуслове. Это уже не тряпочный Семен, а вполне осознающий свои действия Николай, но с присущим ему шармом. Иногда в тексте будут проскальзывать очевидные противоречия, но к концу такого опять же становится поменьше.

Так что же по итогу? Если вы следили за разработкой с самого начала, поддержали игру еще в 2016 и болезненно реагировали на каждый перенос (а их было много), то игра вполне может вас разочаровать. Я же хоть и поддержал создателей в самом начале, после третьего переноса просто перестал считать дни и оставил сей проект на задворках памяти. И по прошествии всех этих лет, могу сказать, что приятные моменты эта игра подарила, а что еще в принципе нужно. А вот обретет ли она такой же культовый статус как первая игра, покажет лишь время.

120379817.review:
I got into VNs through Everlasting summer, and honestly it started as a joke. But in the end it turned out to be one of my favourite gaming/reading experience and I enjoyed it a lot. I tried other VNs (Doki doki, Grisaia etc.) however even though I enjoyed them somehow, they kinda failed to excite me about the story or the characters in the same way ES did. I was about to drop this genre for a while with occasional revisits to ES, but then I learned that LMR is going to be released soon (luckily for me I encountered ES relatively recently, so I didn't have to wait X years for the release of this new game). 

Immediatelly I tried the demo for fun, and quickly realised that's exacly what I needed/wanted to play and read. I got so into the story I was reading it until like 4 am until my gf came across to tell me I am probably retarded. I explored every possible option and put almost 20 or more hours just into the demo alone - that should be the first hint about how awesome this game is. It was way better unlike all the other novels I tried so far and the full game offers like 4 times more content just within the one chosen path. 

Of course this game is also way more complex and better than the original ES. It seems more mature and serious. The kickstarter money and time spent developing the story really is recognazible at first sight. CGs are no longer simple, characters backgrounds are well written. The whole story can be thrilling, is full of tension and romance with funny moments at the same time as well. 

I just finished the game for the first time and got Ellie's good ending. I am looking forward to explore the other girls paths and endings as all of them now seemed quite likeable and even intriguing (for example in ES I never really cared from the start about Ulyana or Miku and I just played their paths because I was a bit curious how they look like - but here I know now that I am really interested in all the heroines as each of them have their own charm and mysterious backstory. 

Also I checked some of the early comments and I was surprised about the occasional dislike for the main character. I realise I am not exactly the target audience of the classic VN genre, but it always irritated me that the main protagonist in VNs is usually a completely blind idiot, who cannot understand why this particular woman is asking him to go for a naked swim together and then few chapters later is immensely surprised that the girl likes him. I get for who they are usually written for, but even so it always feels too much or extreme even. That's what I liked about Grisaia - the main protagonist kinda had some balls there.

 In LMR though, I liked how the main protagonist was thinking and reasoning a lot. Yes Nick had some outbursts and thought about Catherine a lot at the start, but honesly given the background of the story it makes perfect sense. He was in love with the girl, she suddenly left and he was recovering a year and a half from this breakup. And now imagine she's back - even if you would have already eyes for another girl, that would mess up with your head a lot. Also take into account the other mystery circumstances which start to affect our hero through the story and you have a textbook example of a candidate for a nervous breakdown or therapy. I still think he handled it quite well (with our help with the choices of course:)

I don't want to write a novel here by myself too, so I will just highlight some other features or characteristics which I loved about the game:

The soundtrack is fucking awesome. Combination with the 80's synthwave (even more now with the Stranger things OST mania) and electric guitar rock is the ultimate combo. I truly plan to buy a guitar and learn some of the riffs for myself (I hope dozens experts on youtube will help a lot). 

I really like how each girl distinguishly differs from each other, but not by typical "VN classes" like tsundere, yandere but just by pure writing and their personality and background. Also it seems, that there is bigger rivalry between some girls more than with the others, which I honestly find brilliant. 

The CGs are beatiful to look at and the animation is pretty cool too. At first it was a bit weird, but in the end I liked it more and more. 

It's nice that there are actually some male friends of the protagonist as well, it looks more immersive. Also some lines from Kyosuke were the funniest moments in the game as I happen to have a similar friend into anime. 

Even though I know the characters are made up and it's just a simple story, you could really say the feelings you get from reading the novels are real. Like for a few days you can actually have a crush for a nonexistent girl and honestly I realised that it's fine to enjoy it, because there are just too few options for us men to enjoy some romantic content (my gf can just turn on netflix and it's full of love shows for women, but the target audience is clearly not me). 

Also I don't read this to see cartooned tits, so I was not dissapointed by the lack of adult content let's say, especially when there are plenty lines and hints about characters having regular sex, so I am glad that it's not an eroge fixated only to describe some unrealistic sex/porn lines (which no one ever says during sex, maybe for fun), intercourse is just displayed as a normal part of a healthy relationship and again, I see this as a big plus. 

All in all I think the story was full of plotwists, but just so balanced that it's not boring and in the same time not too crazy, so it is still somewhat believable like it could happen (well no, but it's not impossible let's say).

I think it's definitely worth the money (altough I got it through preorder for like half the price - I would still pay the 20 euro without hesitation now when I know how much quality content there is) so if you are not sure, definitely give it a shot! 

PS. Maybe what I really enjoy about Soviet games studio's novels is that there is some European influence which makes their novels stand out among others and thus being somewhat unique, plus even the occasional philosophizing of the protagonist sometimes has something in it which can resonate within me.

PSS. Of course my anime friend already found an 18+ patch on vndb (and yeah of course I am at least going to try it out geez I am not a saint).

EDIT:
After finishing all the routes, I have to admit, that the two main paths are seriously different, which can have it's pros and cons.

Pros - it's great that you are reading a completely new content, and I really liked the plot twist with Catherine's reasons for her departure and early behaviour. This path also seemed somewhat more realistic. Himitsu's romance surprised me in quality, it's really much better written than I expected. 

Cons - Nick's behaviour is kinda different within each main path, especially during Catherine's route and to be honest now I get some of the hate for our hero - he drinks way way more here (and that comes from someone who does not mind hanging out over a beer or so) and he really argues a lot with almost everybody around him. I still stand for my words above, that it still seems kinda logical due to the circumstances, however the differences in his behaviour are truly significant in comparion to the Ellie/Kagome path. 120315102.review:
[b]The Good:[/b]
- Great art, unique visuals, kind of a mix between anime and Disney.
- Crisp smooth animations and good cut-scene art.
- Story has strong beginning and middle, does a good job of setting the atmosphere and tone for the rest of the game. Really sucks you into the world and the time period.
- The girls are all unique with their own characteristics, you won’t find the typical VN stereotypes here.
- A E S T H E T I C - if Japanese 80s style environments are your thing, can’t go wrong here.
- Music is top notch, seriously great tracks, all bangers.

[b]The Meh:[/b]
- Translation issues (probably patched by now)
- "Brevity is the soul of wit" apparently the writer didn't get this message cause dialogue can drone on and get repetitive. I swear characters have the same conversations/arguments multiple times.
- Choices... unless you have the Russian walk-through, which you can find in 'guides', it’s hard to determine which direction your character will go. The game is based on a points system, so your choices can add or subtract points from your desired ending, and it isn't always clear.
- Sometimes the music doesn’t fit the tone of the current scene. The Music will be fast paced or suspenseful, giving the indication that something interesting is about to happen, but then it doesn’t. Its best just to have silence then the wrong track.

[b]The Bad:[/b]
- So, I played the Kagome ending so far and if it’s any indication of the other paths, then I have some concerns. The ending of that path was... disappointing. It sort of just happened. It built up to, what appeared to be, a very interesting climax that you thought was going to go somewhere, but then it suddenly resolved itself. I don't want to spoil anything but the huge conflict literally ends with a phone call and a walk in the park. No, I’m not being facetious or using the phrase "a walk in the park", I'm being literal. How it happened, who the new characters were, what happened to the old characters, and how they came to be there, are all left a mystery and it was very difficult to follow. Is this due to a translation issues? Does this make more sense in Russian then English? I doubt it as the rest of the game was pretty easy to follow until that point. The ending left questions that were completely unanswered and some serious plot holes: [spoiler] What happened to Akira and what deal did he make with the KGB? I thought Akira was locked up, why did he suddenly appear in the park? Why did Jun stop going after you and Kagome after the KGB took Akira? If Akira went with the KGB, why did Jun not seek revenge on you for being responsible for giving Akira to his enemies? Who the fuck is Mikhail? Were Nikos' parents actually assassinated or was it just an accident? Were his parents’ defectors from the Soviet Union or were they spies?  [/spoiler] so many questions but the game would like to pretend that it all wrapped up nicely. Which is especially annoying cause I had such high hopes for the ending and hoped that many of my questions would be answered.
- The story arc I followed also makes a big deal about your parents, spoiler ahead: [spoiler] being dead. At a certain point in the game, it is revealed that the Kobayashi corporation, Kobayashi Jun’s company, could have been responsible for the death of your parents over a year and a half ago, killing them because he believed they were corporate spies sending information back to the USSR. So what does the protagonist do when he finds this information out? Well… kinda nothing. When he meets face to face with Jun, the topic is barely brought up, except to reveal that Jun believed them to be spies. I honestly expected this to be a bigger plot point, considering how big of a deal it is. The potential was there to make this into a revenge story where the protag avenges his dead parents and saves the girl or dies trying, or something along those lines; and I know it’s a trope at this point, but Chekhov's Gun dictates that SOMETHING should be done with that plot device, or else why bring it up so often. [/spoiler]
- As stated in ‘The Good:’ The girls are all unique with their own characteristics, you won’t find the typical VN stereotypes here. That’s a double-edged sword, as… phew, some of these girls have iiiiiiiiissues. As another reviewer said, picking your favorite girl is like picking your favorite poison.
- The story is more “reactive” then “active”. As in, things will happen to the protagonist, and he will react to them. Very little “active” planning is going on. Having a reactive story in the beginning is fine as the protag is a HS student and needs to adjust to the events of the plot, but at some point, you’d expect the protag to be more active in directing the plot his way and controlling his destiny. Any time active plot decisions happens from the protag, its poorly planned, and sometimes nonsensical. Maybe that’s to be expected because he’s a HS student, but it’s disappointing that more clever writing wasn’t incorporated into the characters decisions.

[b]The REALLY Bad:[/b]
OMG shut the fuck up about Katherine, seriously, shut the fuck up. You can’t make me care about your ex-gf if she’s a frigid bitch every time she’s on screen talking to you. I’m literally almost at the end of the Kagome arc, and this fucker is still talking about Katherine.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
I recommend this game lol. I know it sounds like I criticized it a lot, but that’s only because the game really sucked me in until the ending, where I was left going “huh?” which is never a reaction you want from your reader. It’s one thing to have a bad ending, but its another thing to have a confusing one where you have to reread dozens of lines of dialogue to find out where you are and how you got there. Maybe I need to play the rest of the girls’ ‘good’ endings to get a better understanding of the plot, but from what I’ve seen so far, the dev should have delayed the game another month or two to iron out some story elements, and it would have been a masterpiece. This game reminds me a lot of Mass Effect 3 in terms of how it made me feel. Fantastic game with excellent story and great narrative, only to fall apart at the end because of strange writing decisions.

Verdict: Solid 7/10, maybe 7.5

120271078.review:
Wow, how am I supposed to describe this! Going through one route was definitely an adventure!

Before I actually start this, I have to say that you should only take seriously reviews that were made with WAY more that 10 hours by the time of review. That's not nearly enough time to read adequately and finish a single route.

The writing (English translation, not original Russian):

Usually characters in visual novels are very two dimensional, generic, and sometimes outright boring. In LMR you won't find these stereotypical personalities, such as the tsundere, the hard worker, and the lazybones. Each character has been created with their own in-depth backgrounds which form the characters into who they are at the start of the VN, and they can change along the way, too. A great example of this is the main character himself. Many people seem to complain about the character, saying that he's too hotblooded, volatile, etc, however anyone who has experiences at least some of what he has will understand him. His background isn't just a plot device, it formed the MC into the extremely stressed vegetable he is at the start of the game, and you see him mellow out by the end. If you don't like the complexity of characters and just want to read more VNs full of Mary Sues, this VN probably isn't for you, but it is for me. 

TL;DR: The characters are onions. 10/10

When it comes to reading (it isn't an audiobook, so no voice acting), it is for the most part simple enough. However when it gets to the more philosophical parts, it can get a bit complicated, however it really isn't a significant blow to the VN. For the English translation (important to note that this isn't a big developer company full of professionals), there are some grammar mistakes and typos, but these can generally be ignored and don't hamper the reading experience much.

TL;DR: Easy enough to read well for dummies. 7/10

The plot of LMR clearly developed way before its setting. Like the characters, it is a product of past events, and like the characters, it's full of layers. It's a really well crafted, detailed story that you won't get all the answers for in one sitting, and I doubt questions that aren't answered ever don't have answers due to the detail in the craftsmanship. 

TL;DR (somehow): The story is just as onion-y as the characters are. 10/10


Music:

The OST is absolutely amazing! Fantastic! Boss! Sometimes TOO good! At times I just have to stop whatever I'm doing and start busting out some moves! On a more serious note, the OST is excellent, there's an extremely wide variety of songs so you won't be listening to exactly the same thing for an hour. And you can listen to the songs in the gallery which is even better cause I love the OST of LMR.

TL;DR: Read the paragraph. 12/10

Ok, this review is getting way too long so I'm gonna shorten it from here on.

The sound design is great, too. It organically integrates into the scenes, making the atmosphere work well. A few tweaks here and there could've made it a tad better IMO. 9/10

Art:

The backgrounds are fantastic. I am a big fan of the visuals of LMR, on top of that the backgrounds are all animated! Coupled with great sound design, it really helps to make it feel like the world is alive. 10/10

The character "sprites" are also all animated, making them feel also a lot more alive. For those who don't like it, I'm pretty sure there's a way to disable animations in the settings. And I love the designs! They're really well made! 10/10

The CGs are also all great, the artists definitely put in a lot of work and you can tell! I am a really big fan of the art style of LMR, if you couldn't tell. Many CGs are also animated, so an even bigger bonus! 10/10

My final verdict: 10/10. Love, Money, Rock'n'Roll is an absolute masterpiece of a visual novel. It really emphasises the "visual" part and greatly emphasises the "novel" part, so if all you want is the generic VN with the predictable plot, simple characters and unfunny humour just for the horny points, this VN is not for you.

120255040.review:
In the first few hours of playing this game, like their previous game Everlasting Summer, I was hooked on the world that Soviet Games has created. This game was absolutely filled with love over many long years of development. 

I have decided to change my review after I have had 0 interest in coming back to the game.

Look: This game is far from perfect. It has some glaring issues and some major differences from Everlasting Summer (for those who played). This however does not mean that it is a bad game. Some of the issues can be fixed with 1 or 2 patches, others may never be fixed. TLDR; here are the Pros and Cons.

Cons:
- One of my big issues is that the main plot. The story feels like it was rehashed over and over and over again in the long years of development. While the story itself is well written, it misses the mark like it's sister story, Everlasting summer. Being railroaded down 4 different options with 0 meaningful interactions between characters with left me with a bitter taste more than a sense of satisfaction. I felt this game could use different endings that add intrigue (see the Yulya, Miku, and Seymon endings from ES). 
- Some "cut scene" animations do look rushed and not polished, leading to unsettling and almost hollow looking characters.

Pros:
- Great Music
- Beautiful Art for background scenes
- Great replayability (if looking to do all endings or even just more than one route)
- Will engross you in at least one story line for at least 4-9 hours 
- IMO convincing, believable, characters.
- IMO great idea and story for a VN, interesting - if not crazy - story lines

Neutral:
- Atypical anime art style. I personally enjoy it, your mileage may vary.
- English translation does have some grammatical errors, but they are easy to look around.
- The main character is not a giga-chad. He is written with his own background, his own issues, and a whole life before the game takes place. He very much may not be a character that everyone will like. He is imperfect, along with every other character in the game. Your mileage may vary

120230126.review:
They say that a chain is only as strong as its weakest link, and this game is a perfect example of the adage. For its seven years of development, Love, Money, Rock'n'Roll was shaping up to be lightning in a bottle. And for seven years, I was confident that LMR would rock the western VN audience. And with each devlog, which I religiously followed, this confidence only grew. CGs were showcased and tracks from the OST released, proving the skill of the artists and composers beyond any doubt. It looked as if the game would quench those years of hype that had accumulated. The chain was was proving to be very strong. 

For a game that has an atmosphere so incredibly intoxicating, for a game that looks so good, has music tracks that stick in your mind, and offers so much narrative potential, the scenario writer thoroughly fumbled every opportunity to take the story to exciting places, to utilise the setups for satisfying payoff or to play with the unique quirks of the setting, and more inherently problematic, failed to have his characters embark on adventures, to change and grow and complete their goals. In a sense, it has a beginning and a middle, but no end. Aragorn rises from obscurity as a mysterious ranger, wrestles with his sense of duty and his destiny as King of Gondor, and then doesn't do anything about it at all.

The scenario writer, as skilled as he is, no matter how much introspection and monologue is served, as the most important link in the chain, he failed to capitalise on anything the scenario actually offered. Any fan could suggest more compelling ideas and exercise the full range of creative motion that the writer did not, which is why I look forward to when workshop support is released. Hopefully then, I can find a group of like-minded people to work with to realise this wasted potential one day. 

Overall, LMR is a great experience, with a woefully under utilised setting, charming characters, an incredible soundtrack and art that all together create an atmosphere second only to one other Visual Novel, of which almost makes up for the flaws of its narrative. 

Then go and play Yakuza 0 for a nice follow up. From 1987 to 1988.

Kagome a best.

120221904.review:
Love, Money, Rock’n’Roll is a visual novel set in the late 80’s, that revolves around mystery and intrigues, betrayal and sacrifice, hatred and passion. I am not well-versed when it comes to visual novels. In fact, this is my first time encountering this developer, Soviet Games. And I am intrigued when I found out that they have a very well received game, Everlasting Summer, under their belt. 

It has also amazes me how long this game has been in works. Apparently, this game has been in Kickstarter in 2016. Though I am only been aware of its existence for a few days, I am glad to know that it was able to finally see a release after all those years of development.

Those background arts took me back to the good old ways of hand drawn anime style. This time around with a little bit of modern touch as they come alive/animated at some point. The characters are also fully animated during dialogues, which I really appreciate when compared to the other visual novels. They feel more alive when compared to others wherein the character are static and in a blink of an eye, changes their posing throughout the dialogues. 

I am definitely not yet halfway through the story, but I am eager to find out what ending I’ll be achieving in my first playthrough. Please take note that there are no hidden Steam Achievements, therefore if you have taken a quick peek on them then you may already have an idea on some possible endings. Which I hope I am wrong, since I would’ve slightly spoiled myself if what I’m seeing based on the graphics of these achievements is what I am thinking. 

Probably my only gripe with this game is that there are no any type of voiceovers. I wasn’t expecting any fully voiced dialogues, but some sort of voice lines that align with their dialogues would’ve been such a better experience. Hearing the characters giggling, grunting, groan, etc. would definitely make this visual novel more immersive in my opinion.

Personally, I think the UI for this visual novel fits with what they are trying to do. It is not overly cluttered and the little effects they have in between are a nice touch. They even included two options for the ‘Appearance’ of the game: Classic or Immersive, with the latter adding some level of fuzziness to the screen. And then there’s also two options for ‘GUI Style’: Classic or Modern, which I think only changes the settings screen as far as I know. 

Recalling dialogues are also easy to do. For someone like me who tends to miss click and accidentally moved to the next dialogue, knowing there is an easy way to re-read previous line is such a relief. I know it’s not a big deal to some and its probably been done more often than not, but I am happy report this game contains this little quality of life feature.

In general, I highly recommend this game to anyone who are looking for a visual novel with a rich story, great soundtrack, interesting characters, and a top-notch artwork/art style. What captivated me towards this visual novel, was specifically the art style.

120199829.review:
The short version: In my opinion it's a very well crafted visual novel and fully worth grabbing if you enjoy visual novels with great music and stories. That said let me get to the long version.

This is one that I've been waiting for since they first announced it a while ago. As a big fan of Everlasting Summer I was excited to see this visual novel come to fruition, and with such polish and pizazz as well! Makes it feel worth the wait. I do hope people don't judge this one too harshly as Everlasting Summer kind of set a high bar for our friends at Soviet Games, and I feel like it might be harshly criticized based on that... With that said, I have to say I'm honestly really impressed with how it's turned out so far. 

First is the animations that I wasn't expecting, from the character movements to the backgrounds. They're fluid, give extra life to the visual novel, and honestly are just very pleasing to watch while reading. Plus all the amount of details in the backgrounds are pleasing to sweep through (at least to me since I like to look around a new area before I read more)

Next is the music. I love it to put it simply. The soundtrack is honestly just full of bangers and really set the mood in several scenes. This is one area I feel is a large improvement over Everlasting Summer. Plus several of them have an apparent 80's vibe about them which I personally really like.

The story so far is fairly great as well! Lots of different options to choose from and I've seen a couple unexpected twists so far that have kept me delving further to see what would happen next.

I give this visual novel high praise but I will say that the main protagonist isn't one I can as easily relate to as someone like Semyon from Everlasting Summer. This could also be because Everlasting Summer's protagonist was a lot more open ended in their thinking compared to our main protagonist Nickolai. In that I mean our choices made in Everlasting Summer more or less would be reciprocated in the inner dialogue of the protagonist compared to our man Nickolai in this visual novel. With that said, I wouldn't consider it a bad thing as this visual novel doesn't reach as far out to the obscure as Everlasting Summer did. And that likely might not even be the point of the visual novel as it is set in a completely different setting, with new people, and a seemingly intriguing story to tell on it's own accord. All in all though, I do kind of wish our boy Nickolai was a little bit more relatable in some of the choices made.

With all this said, I do highly recommend this to anyone like myself who doesn't read too far into the visual novels and just enjoys a good read with nice visuals and music to boot! Make sure you guys show the developer some love as well if you like it as this visual novel was a long time in the making and I feel the polish this one received is top notch. 

Also I must add that Himitsu is such a sweetheart! Love her to death. 

To the developers, great job peeps and can't wait to see what y'all come up with next! I'll be watching and waiting after I finish this one.

120156807.review:
The review needs an update, so here we go.
By all means I did like the game and I do recommend it, but my review goes a little bit beyond that. 
The project development process was dragged for quite a while and community meme'd on it rather harshly for nearly 6 years. Now, that's an important information, if one tries to understand why so many people might feel betrayed or, at the very least, frustrated. The majority of players, however, can agree on undisputed quality of art and soundtrack. Writing though is where things get really spicy and complex. I believe It's been debated since the very release up until now, tons of brown sauce was spilled and whatnot, which is honestly understandable... in a way, to a certain extent. 
I have to admit that It's really hard to put many things aside for the sake of keeping oneself from biased opinions as people tend to be hard-stuck into dealing in absolutes, but my personal take is that "the point system to get a certain ending" very well might be a dead-end rigid mechanic for the VN genre as a whole. If we look back at the timeline of each gaming genre development, we can see how specific game mechanics got implemented and tested for survivability. Regardless of their (mechanics) significance, it is undeniably required for them to be improved, renovated, even discarded and reframed for the new iteration of projects so the given genre can evolve and bring new experience. In case of LMR particularly, I'm not entirely sure which route was the most optimal. However, it is evident to me that the more detailed and complex story you try to tell, the more brutal and limiting are the gimmicks of the point system. It gets to the point where this particular system forces its limitations and holds the plot hostage, so you're trapped in searching for bizzare compromises (honestly, can't even imagine how hard and brain-wrecking it can be). Therefore, I think the community needs to debate more about core issues with the point system and search for a better solution and alternatives rather than throwing feces at each other like monkeys, only then we might get some productive dialogue and conclusion.

120153828.review:
[СПОЙЛЕРЫ]

при всём уважении к красивым музыке и артам, играть за гг просто невыносимо. выборов очень мало и большинство из них кажутся довольно бессмысленными, скучными и ленивыми. На примере рута Эли (спойлеры!): первая сцена с порошком где можно согласиться/отказаться вне зависимости от выбора игрока приведёт к тому что гг попробует порошок и все дальнейшие сцены будут такими же, однако из-за этого маленького выбора велик шанс улететь на плохую концовку Эли где в ключевом моменте (разговор с Кагомэ) поведение персонажа резко меняется на противоположное, он резко забывает что всё это время любил Эли, и делает диаметрально противоположное тому что вам кажется логичным из-за того что у вас на руте недобор в 1 очко. если уж делать бальную систему, то добавлять больше выборов, и больше осмысленных выборов, чтобы не возникало ощущение что на поведение героя повлиять вообще никак нельзя. 

собственно, остальные выборы выглядят ещё более скучными: поддержать Кагомэ/Эли, пообедать с Эли или одному, сказать Эли комплимент или не говорить. Такое дерево дерево решений можно придумать за 2 дня, уж никак не за 7 лет, и когда из таких решений состоит практически весь рут играть становится скучно 

К сожалению, вне зависимости от выборов и от рута герой большую часть игры будет вести себя как дебил, нести бред и вам придётся это терпеть

120133721.review:
Обзор пишу до прохождения и трети концовок, что здесь есть, но уже могу сказать одно.

Денег потраченных не жалею. Я не был фанатиком, который обижался на перенос игры, просто знал, что когда она выйдет, я буду рад. И было мне плевать, прожду я еще год или два. Dreamtale - талант, кто бы что ни говорил. Сценарий прелестный.

Однако и поругать игру мне, пожалуй, стоит. По мере прохождения я столкнулся с несколькими техническими проблемами, игнорировать существование которых невозможно. Такими, например, стали хардлок aka черный экран после загрузки сохранений или даже (!) начале новой игры, без возможности даже в меню выйти. Решением стало только полное удаление игры (и то, вручную) и проверка кэша после этого. И то, пришлось начать заново (благо, функция перемотки помогает за 10 минут нагнать тот же самый момент, где я остановился.
Во-вторых, это незначительные ошибки в тексте. Например, одна из героинь узнает, что у главного героя умерли родители, но через пять минут спрашивают, почему их нет дома, после чего главный герой вновь это объясняет. Ещё пример - заметил пару проблем со сносками. Они используются для пояснения каких-то терминов и выделяются оранжевым. Один из терминов был написан дважды в самой реплике - "[b]термин[/b]термин". Или, например, термин "японский милитаризм" был объяснён сноской как "японский милитаризм".
В-третьих, после титров игра намертво зависает. Приходится юзать альт-ф4. 

Однако даже все эти косяки не позволят мне отговаривать вас от покупки игры. Напротив! Российских игр на рынке и так немного, так давайте же поддержим отечественного разработчика. Спасибо за внимание!
